chunks.original_text: 四十三年甲寅，老君降，乘白鹿，登庭桧之杪而飞升。 今有升天鹿迸在亳州太清官。 祖庚元年辛未，在位一十七年。 祖甲元年戊子，在位一十七年。 直辛元年乙巳，在位六年。 庚丁元年辛亥，在位二十一年。 武乙元年壬申，在位四年。 侮慢上天，暴雷击死。 太丁元年丙子，在位四年。 帝乙元年庚辰，在位二十七年。 辛纣元年丁未，在位二十七年，终癸酉。 二十一年丁卯，老君降于岐山之阳，号燮邑子。 周文王为西伯，召为守藏史。 世本云：老子在商为柱下史。 郑玄注《论语》云：老彭，商之贤大夫也。 孔颖达疏：言老是老聘。 周武王 姬姓，木德，建子为正月，起癸酉，灭商，即位九十六年。 子孙继立者八百六十五年。 迁老君为柱下史。 《史记》及刘钦《七略》皆云为周守藏史。 葛洪及《内传》云：文王时为守藏史，武王时为柱下史。 唯刘向《列仙传》云：生於商时，为周柱下史，转为守藏史。 既生於商，其为两史，故当在文王之世。 然或先或后，特未定尔。 按扬雄《方言》云：尝闻伐辑轩之史，秦籍之书·皆藏於周、秦之室。 又《庄子》云：孔子将西藏书於周室，子路谋日：由闻周征藏史有老聘者，藏室云者，皆考证於老子，故日征藏。 夫子欲藏书，则试往因之。 盖仲尼将藏书，以老子尝为史官，请知藏室，前言往行，故先访之也。 按《周礼》王、太史、内史、外史、御史，几五史，诸侯亦有国史，故《礼记》君动则左史书之，言则左史书之。 左史视礼，内史、太史为诸史之长，掌四方之志。 三皇五帝之书藏之於室，故谓之守藏史。 周幽王时有伯阳父，唐固注云：周柱下史老子也。 烈王有太史借，修亦老子也。 太史为周下大夫，谓五史之任总之太史，记言记事，尝在君前柱下，即史官所立之处，因为曹局之名。 而韦昭云：伯阳为大夫者，谓职为太史官，即下大夫也。 史记称张苍好书历，秦时为御史大夫，主柱下方书。 据《周礼》，御史掌赞书及赞教，几其方书及内史所掌，此秦官不与周同也。 世本云在商为守藏史，在周为柱下史，盖文王以侯服事商，未得称一周耳，则先为守藏，后居柱下无疑矣。 刘向之言，谓先聘为太史，以其静退，却为他史，当老子时，复更免归。 烈王之时，又为太史，一居周世，时历数王。 故亦遍参诸史，是以守藏、柱，下先后不同。 班固云：老聘者，周之老史，游於柱下，以究高年。 据固之言，则为累代史官，故称老史。 隋内史薛道衡撰《祠庭颂》，其序云：爰自伏牺至於周氏，绵纪历代，见质变名。 在文王、武王之时，居藏史、柱史之职，市朝累易，容貌不改。 成王
chunks.translated_text:
In the forty-third year, *jiayin*, the Venerable Lord descended, riding a white deer, and ascended to the heavens from the treetop of a cypress in the courtyard. Today, the deer’s hoofprints from his ascension remain at the Supreme Clarity Palace in Bozhou.

**Reigns of Shang Kings:**
- Year one of Zu Geng, *xinhai*: reigned seventeen years.
- Year one of Zu Jia, *wuzǐ*: reigned seventeen years.
- Year one of Lin Xin, *yǐsì*: reigned six years.
- Year one of Kang Ding, *xīnhài*: reigned twenty-one years.
- Year one of Wu Yi, *rénshēn*: reigned four years. He disrespected Heaven and was struck dead by violent thunder.
- Year one of Tai Ding, *bǐngzǐ*: reigned four years.
- Year one of Di Yi, *gēngchén*: reigned twenty-seven years.
- Year one of Xin Zhou, *dīngwèi*: reigned twenty-seven years, ending in *guǐyǒu*.

In the twenty-first year, *dīngmǎo*, the Venerable Lord descended upon the southern slopes of Mount Qi, styled as the Master of Xieyi. King Wen of Zhou, then Lord of the West, summoned him to serve as Archivist of the Royal Treasury. The *Generational Records* state: "Laozi served as Archivist Beneath the Pillars in the Shang." Zheng Xuan’s commentary on the *Analects* notes: "Lao Peng was a virtuous minister of Shang." Kong Yingda’s subcommentary clarifies: "Lao refers to Lao Dan."

King Wu of Zhou, of the Ji clan, embodied the virtue of Wood. He established the first month as *zǐ* and began his reign in *guǐyǒu*, overthrowing Shang and ascending the throne. His dynasty endured for ninety-six years, with his descendants ruling for eight hundred and sixty-five years in succession. The Venerable Lord was then appointed Archivist Beneath the Pillars.

The *Records of the Grand Historian* and Liu Xin’s *Seven Summaries* both state he served as Archivist of the Royal Treasury in Zhou. Ge Hong and the *Inner Transmission* record: "He was Archivist of the Royal Treasury during King Wen’s reign and Archivist Beneath the Pillars during King Wu’s reign." Only Liu Xiang’s *Biographies of Transcendents* claims: "Born in the Shang, he served as Archivist Beneath the Pillars in Zhou, later becoming Archivist of the Royal Treasury." Since he was born in the Shang, his tenure as both archivists must have occurred during King Wen’s era. However, the sequence—whether he served first or later—remains uncertain.

According to Yang Xiong’s *Regional Speech*: "I have heard that the records of the *Faji* and *Xuan* offices, along with the books of Qin’s archives, were all stored in the chambers of Zhou and Qin." The *Zhuangzi* also states: "Confucius intended to deposit books in the Zhou archives. Zilu advised, 'I have heard that the Archivist of Zhou’s Treasury, Lao Dan, is in charge of the archives. Since you wish to store books there, why not seek his counsel?' Confucius, intending to deposit the books, approached Laozi because he had once held the office of archivist and thus knew the treasury’s affairs. His past conduct and experience made him the natural choice."

The *Rites of Zhou* enumerates five types of historians: the Royal Historian, Grand Historian, Inner Historian, Outer Historian, and Censor. Feudal lords also maintained state historians. The *Book of Rites* records: "When the ruler acts, the Left Historian records it; when he speaks, the Right Historian records it." The Left Historian observed ritual, while the Inner Historian and Grand Historian oversaw all historians, preserving the records of the Four Directions. The books of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors were stored in the treasury, hence the title "Archivist of the Royal Treasury."

During the reign of King You of Zhou, Boyang Fu was active. Tang Gu’s commentary identifies him as Laozi, the Archivist Beneath the Pillars. During the reign of King Lie, the Grand Historian Jie—also Laozi—served. The Grand Historian was a senior minister of Zhou, overseeing the five historians. Responsible for recording words and deeds, he stood beneath the pillars in the ruler’s presence, hence the name of the office. Wei Zhao explains: "Boyang held the rank of Grandee, serving as Grand Historian, which was a position of lower grandee."

The *Records of the Grand Historian* notes that Zhang Cang, who excelled in calendrical studies, served as Censor during the Qin, overseeing the archives beneath the pillars. According to the *Rites of Zhou*, the Censor assisted in documentation and instruction, managing the archives and records under the Inner Historian’s purview. This Qin office differed from Zhou’s system.

The *Generational Records* state: "In the Shang, he was Archivist of the Royal Treasury; in Zhou, he was Archivist Beneath the Pillars." Since King Wen, as a vassal, served the Shang and could not yet be considered ruler of an independent Zhou, it is certain he first served as Archivist of the Royal Treasury and later as Archivist Beneath the Pillars. Liu Xiang’s account suggests Lao Dan initially served as Grand Historian but, due to his quiet and retiring nature, was reassigned to another historian’s post. By Laozi’s time, he had retired again. During King Lie’s reign, he returned as Grand Historian, serving multiple Zhou kings in a single lifetime. Thus, he held various historian roles, with the sequence of Archivist of the Royal Treasury and Archivist Beneath the Pillars differing.

Ban Gu writes: "Lao Dan was Zhou’s elder historian, who wandered beneath the pillars, investigating the ways of longevity." According to Ban’s account, he served as a historian across multiple reigns, hence the title "elder historian."

During the Sui dynasty, the Inner Historian Xue Daoheng composed the *Eulogy of the Temple Courtyard*, whose preface states: "From Fuxi to the Zhou, spanning successive dynasties, he witnessed transformations in substance and name. During the reigns of Kings Wen and Wu, he held the offices of Archivist of the Royal Treasury and Archivist Beneath the Pillars. Though courts and markets changed, his appearance remained unaltered. King Cheng..."

chunks.original_text: 元年戊寅，在位四十七年。 老君仍为柱下史，号经成子。 授道周公，乃游西极大秦、竺乾等国，号古先生。 按《老子内传》云： 伏牺时号郁华子，神农时号传豫子，祝融时号广寿子，轩辕时号广成子，颛帝时号赤精子，帝誉时号录图子， 唐尧时号务成子，虞舜时号尹寿子，夏禹时号宁真子， 作真行子商汤时号锡则子，又文王、武王，几为十二帝师。 梁黄门侍郎萧子云撰《清虚馆》碑亦云：太虚辽廓，迸绝言象，应感攸通，缘物致称。 伯阳降娠，垂发皓素。 尧曰务成，舜曰尹寿，赤精当生於颛帝，录图出自於神农。 得一含元，王资始。 又日：遨神九天之上，道百精魏阙之下，巍巍荡荡，莫得而名云。 旧记并以老君在神农时为大成子，帝誉时为录图子，此碑独谓录图出自神农，而《内传》又谓神农时为传豫子，谅未能无少误，要当以经传为正。 抱朴子葛洪作《神仙传》，疑历代为帝师，谓皆见碎书，不出仙传正经。 又谓不应背澄清而入臭浊，弃天官而受人爵。 且日：有天地则有道衍，道卫之士世世有之，何叉常是一老子耶。 皆由晚学之徒好奇尚异，欲推尊老子，故有此说耳。 唐昊天观主尹文操尝着论驶之日：抱朴撰传，意在显迷。 老君起自修成，将以训诱后人，令其勉力，故云若谓老子是得道之人，则人又勉力竞慕，若谓是神灵，则非可学也。 斯其臆见耳，殊不知开辟之始，因学而得道者叉有自然圣降而为师，随机传受焉。 《定志经》云：昔天尊造大慈之初，行应自然，暗与理合，自然玄悟，本无文字，撰集成经，以教将来尔。 由是观之，则老君自然学道，而世世为师，亦何疑焉。 既为大慈之父，亦何辞拾尊就卑，和光臭浊乎。 老子谓关尹子日：上世以来，所更如沙尘，动则有载却，自惟甚苦勤。 《太玄经》亦云：老子积学轮转，位登上圣，应接无方，不可称迷。 近世出化，生乎殷末。 虞宣《出塞记》云：老子凝神太玄之卿，分灵散景，世世下教。 鹤山崔元《濑乡记》云：老子应见，代代有之。 葛仙公云：开辟以前，下为国师，世世不休。 文始、鬼谷、张辅汉并云：老君生乎太无之先，经历天地，不可称载。 此岂谓碎书与晚学浅见道欤。 稚川特未之思耳。 康王
chunks.translated_text:
In the first year of his reign, the cyclical year wuyin, he ruled for forty-seven years. The Venerable Lord still served as Archivist Beneath the Pillars, styled Master of Scriptural Completion. He transmitted the Dao to the Duke of Zhou, then journeyed to the westernmost lands of Da Qin and the realms of Zhuqian, where he was known as the Ancient Master.

According to the *Inner Traditions of Laozi*: In the time of Fuxi, he was styled Master Yuhua; during the era of Shennong, Master Chuanyu; under Zhurong, Master Guangshou; in the age of the Yellow Emperor, Master Guangcheng; during Zhuanxu’s reign, Master Chijing; under Emperor Ku, Master Lutu; in the time of Yao, Master Wucheng; under Shun, Master Yinshou; during the Xia dynasty under Yu, Master Ningzhen; styled Master Zhenxing in the time of Tang; and Master Xize during the reigns of Kings Wen and Wu—altogether serving as preceptor to twelve sovereigns.

The *Stele of the Pavilion of Clarity and Emptiness*, composed by Xiao Ziyun, Gentleman-in-Attendance of the Yellow Gate during the Liang dynasty, also states: "The Great Void is vast and boundless, transcending speech and form. Responding to stimuli, it acquires names in accordance with things. When Boyang descended in pregnancy, his hair was already white as frost. Yao called him Wucheng; Shun, Yinshou. Chijing was born in the time of Zhuanxu; Lutu emerged from Shennong. Embracing the One and containing the Origin, he became the foundation of kingship." It further declares: "Roaming the spirits above the Nine Heavens, guiding the hundred essences beneath the towering gates, majestic and boundless—none can name him."

Old records uniformly style the Venerable Lord as Master Dacheng during the time of Shennong and Master Lutu under Emperor Ku. This stele alone asserts that Lutu emerged from Shennong, while the *Inner Traditions* calls him Master Chuanyu during Shennong’s era. Surely there must be minor discrepancies; the authoritative texts should be taken as standard.

Ge Hong, in his *Biographies of Divine Transcendents*, casts doubt on the claim that he served as preceptor to successive emperors, arguing that such accounts derive from fragmentary writings rather than the canonical scriptures of transcendence. He further contends that it would be incongruous for one to abandon the clarity of the Dao and enter the foul defilements, or to forsake celestial office for mortal rank. He states: "Where there is Heaven and Earth, there is the unfolding of the Dao, and those who guard it appear in every generation. Why must it always be the same Laozi?" Such views stem from later scholars’ penchant for novelty and their desire to exalt Laozi, hence these assertions.

Yin Wencao, Abbot of the Temple of Heavenly Veneration during the Tang, once composed a refutation, saying: "Ge Hong’s *Biographies* aim to dispel delusion. The Venerable Lord arose through self-cultivation, intending to instruct and guide later generations, urging them to strive diligently. If one claims Laozi was a perfected being, others will emulate him with zeal; if one calls him a divine spirit, he becomes unattainable. This is merely Ge Hong’s personal conjecture, for he fails to recognize that from the very beginning of creation, some attained the Dao through study, while others descended as natural sages to serve as teachers, transmitting the teachings in accordance with circumstances."

The *Scripture of Fixed Resolve* states: "In the beginning, when the Heavenly Worthy established the Great Compassion, he acted in accordance with spontaneity, aligning with principle without conscious effort. His profound awakening was natural, devoid of written words. He compiled scriptures to instruct future generations." From this perspective, the Venerable Lord’s natural mastery of the Dao and his role as preceptor across the ages—what doubt can there be? As the Father of Great Compassion, why would he refuse to descend in humility, harmonizing his light with the foul defilements?

Laozi said to Guan Yinzi: "Since the earliest ages, my transformations have been as numerous as grains of sand. Each movement leaves a record, and I have found it exceedingly arduous." The *Canon of Supreme Mystery* also states: "Laozi accumulated learning through countless cycles, ascending to the rank of supreme sage. His responses were boundless, beyond all reckoning." In recent generations, he manifested his transformations, being born at the end of the Yin dynasty.

Yu Xuan’s *Record of the Northern Frontier* states: "Laozi concentrated his spirit in the ministry of Supreme Mystery, dispersing his numinous radiance to teach in every age." Cui Yuan’s *Record of Lai Village* on Mount Crane says: "Laozi’s manifestations appear in every generation." The Transcendent Lord Ge states: "Before the opening of creation, he descended as preceptor to the nations, continuing without cease." Wen Shi, Gui Gu, and Zhang Fuhan all declare: "The Venerable Lord existed before the Great Non-Being, traversing Heaven and Earth in ways beyond enumeration." How can these be dismissed as fragmentary writings or the shallow views of later scholars? Ge Hong simply failed to consider this.

King Kang.

chunks.original_text: 元年乙丑，在位二十六年。 老君复归于周，号郭叔子，复为柱下史。 昭王 元年辛卯，在位五十年。 老君去官归亳。 二十三年癸丑五月壬午，老君西过函谷关，度关令尹喜。 或谓老君出关虽在周癸丑岁五月壬午，恐非昭王时。 有言幽王时者，今检幽王庚申年立，十一年为犬戎所灭，其时无癸丑岁也。 或谓宣王四十年癸丑五月十八日壬午者，推其岁月四十三年丙辰，老君在渭川，告宣王以周将衰。 幽王二年三川震，老子日：周将亡。 幽王即宣王之子。 若宣王四十年出关，则四十三年不得尚在渭川，幽王时亦不得见三川震也。 平王四十三年，岁亦在癸丑，而五月又无壬午，姚长谦《年帝记》谓景王十年丙寅为孔子师，敬王三十二年癸丑度关。 夫孔子生於灵王之庚戌，至景王丙寅年方十七，未应往师老子也。 况穆王西游，已闻尹真人遇老子，得道飞升。 由是钦慕遗风，遂修楼观，置道士，以奉祠事。 则知老子度关，次不在穆王之后也。 惟《内传》之文与仙公之言符合，自余纷纭之论，终於理义乖违，固不可摭以为实。 二十四年甲寅，老子传道尹喜，授以《道德》五千言，即於喜宅南小山上升天。 是时有五色光贯紫微，井水皆溢。 自商高宗九年至此，凡二百七十四岁也。 二十五年乙卯，老君复分身降生於蜀国李太官家。 前汉刘向《列仙传》云：老子生於商时，为周柱下史，转为守藏史，时称为隐君子。 仲尼见之，知其圣人，乃师之。 乘青牛车去入大秦，关令尹待而迎之。 嵇康、皇甫谧皆云老子生於商末，葛孝先乃谓周时托神李母者，正谓降生於李太官家之时也。 或为商祚将尽，周。 祚已兴，所以商末时生，亦何言周时托化此胎，未铃然也。 二十七年丁巳，老君会尹喜於青羊肆，将去化胡。 故唐纪云：青羊肆者，太上天皇大帝第二降生之所也。 自商道否闭，周德陵夷，历藏史以同尘，弃柱史以隐述，束离魏阙，西度函关。 又云：重为千日之期，再结一时之会，将离蜀土，欲化胡风，远适流沙，长移犷俗及身毒、属西胡雾布纤毛为之宾之国，教烦陀、阿柱之王。 又魏明帝制《老君赞》云：深悯后世，托下於陈，为周柱史，经九百年无极之际。 言归昆仑，化被胡域，次受属宾，后及天竺，於是遂迁。 又《魏略西戎传》、《北史西域传》并云：于阗国西五百里有毗摩寺，云是老子化胡之所也。 出见《唐通典》。 二十八年戊午，老君同尹喜真人降于天水启灵山，今秦州有西升台、圣容殿俱存。 穆王 元年辛巳，在位五十五年，寿一百有五岁。 老君化胡已，即升天。 四年甲申，老君复降於中国，束游扶朵，会大帝，校集群仙。 遂游西海，至苏邻国，号为大光明使，寻即复升天。 穆王闻尹喜真人得道上升，乃为修楼观，立道士七人以奉祠事。 见《穆王内传》及《楼观先生传》。 共王 元年丙子，在位一十二年。 懿王 元年戊子，在位二十五年。 孝王 元年癸丑，在位一十五年。 夷王 元年戊辰，在位一十六年。
chunks.translated_text:
In the first year *yichou* (of his reign), he ruled for twenty-six years. The Venerable Lord returned once more to the Zhou, styled as Guo Shuzi, and again served as Archivist Beneath the Pillars.

In the first year *xinmao* of King Zhao’s reign, he ruled for fifty years. The Venerable Lord resigned his post and returned to Bo. In the twenty-third year *guichou*, on the fifteenth day of the fifth month (*renwu*), the Venerable Lord passed westward through Hangu Pass, where he transmitted the Dao to the Pass Prefect Yin Xi. Some say that though the Venerable Lord’s departure from the pass occurred in the *guichou* year of Zhou, the fifth month, *renwu* day, it was not during King Zhao’s reign. Others claim it was during King You’s time, but upon examination, King You ascended in the *gengshen* year and was overthrown by the Quanrong in his eleventh year, during which there was no *guichou* year. Still others assert it was the fortieth year of King Xuan, *guichou*, the eighteenth day of the fifth month, *renwu*; yet reckoning the years, in the forty-third year *bingchen*, the Venerable Lord was by the Wei River, where he warned King Xuan of Zhou’s impending decline. In the second year of King You, the Three Rivers quaked, and Laozi said, “Zhou will perish.” King You was the son of King Xuan. If the Venerable Lord had departed the pass in the fortieth year of King Xuan, he could not have still been by the Wei River in the forty-third year, nor could he have witnessed the quaking of the Three Rivers during King You’s reign. In the forty-third year of King Ping, the year was also *guichou*, but the fifth month had no *renwu* day. Yao Changqian’s *Annals of Emperors and Kings* states that in the tenth year *bingyin* of King Jing, Confucius became a disciple, and in the thirty-second year *guichou* of King Jing, he transmitted the Dao at the pass. Yet Confucius was born in the *gengxu* year of King Ling, and in the *bingyin* year of King Jing, he was only seventeen—hardly old enough to have studied under Laozi. Moreover, when King Mu journeyed west, he had already heard of Perfected Yin encountering Laozi, attaining the Dao, and ascending in flight. Filled with reverence for this legacy, he then built the Louguan Terrace, established Daoist priests, and instituted sacrificial rites. Thus, it is clear that Laozi’s transmission at the pass did not occur after King Mu’s time. Only the *Inner Transmission* aligns with the words of the Transcendent Lord Ge; all other conflicting accounts ultimately violate reason and principle and cannot be cited as fact.

In the twenty-fourth year *jiayin*, Laozi transmitted the Dao to Yin Xi, bestowing upon him the *Five Thousand Words of the Dao and Its Virtue*. Thereupon, he ascended to Heaven from a small hill south of Yin Xi’s residence. At that time, a five-colored light pierced the Purple Tenuity, and the well waters all overflowed. From the ninth year of High Ancestor of Shang to this time, a total of 274 years had passed.

In the twenty-fifth year *yimao*, the Venerable Lord once more divided his body and descended to be born in the household of Li Taiguan in the state of Shu. Liu Xiang’s *Biographies of the Transcendents* from the Former Han states: “Laozi was born in the Shang era, served as Archivist Beneath the Pillars in Zhou, and later became Keeper of the Archives, known at the time as the Reclusive Gentleman. Confucius met him and, recognizing his sageliness, took him as his teacher. Riding a blue ox-drawn carriage, he departed for the Great Qin, where the Pass Prefect Yin awaited and welcomed him.” Ji Kang and Huangfu Mi both state that Laozi was born at the end of the Shang, while Ge Xiaoxian claims that during the Zhou, he spiritually entered the womb of Li’s mother—referring precisely to the time of his descent into the household of Li Taiguan. Some argue that as the Shang’s mandate neared its end and Zhou’s had already risen, he was born at the close of the Shang; why then speak of his spiritual transformation into this womb during the Zhou? The matter remains unresolved.

In the twenty-seventh year *dingsi*, the Venerable Lord met with Perfected Yin Xi at the Green Ram Market, preparing to depart and transform the Hu. Thus, the *Tang Annals* state: “The Green Ram Market was the second place where the Supreme Heavenly Thearch descended to be born.” From the time the Dao of Shang was obstructed and the virtue of Zhou declined, he passed through the office of Keeper of the Archives, mingling with the world, then abandoned the post of Archivist Beneath the Pillars to conceal his traces. Binding his robes, he departed the Wei Gate and crossed westward through Hangu Pass. It also states: “After a thousand days’ appointed time, they met again for a brief while. About to leave Shu, he sought to transform the customs of the Hu, journeying far to the Flowing Sands, long altering the rough ways of the western barbarians, reaching Shendu and the lands of the western Hu, where woolly and feathered peoples became his guests. He taught the kings of Fanduo and Azhu.” Furthermore, Emperor Ming of Wei composed the *Eulogy for the Venerable Lord*, saying: “Deeply pitying later generations, he descended in Chen to serve as Archivist Beneath the Pillars in Zhou, enduring nine hundred boundless years. Returning to Kunlun, his transforming influence spread to the lands of the Hu, then to Shushen, and later to Tianzhu, whereupon he departed.” The *Wei Lue: Account of the Western Rong* and the *Northern History: Account of the Western Regions* both state: “Five hundred *li* west of Yutian is the Pimo Monastery, said to be where Laozi transformed the Hu.” This is recorded in the *Tang Comprehensive Institutions*.

In the twenty-eighth year *wuwu*, the Venerable Lord and Perfected Yin Xi descended upon Qiling Mountain in Tianshui. Today, in Qinzhou, the Western Ascent Terrace and the Hall of the Sage’s Countenance both remain.

In the first year *xinsi* of King Mu’s reign, he ruled for fifty-five years and lived to the age of one hundred and five. After transforming the Hu, the Venerable Lord ascended to Heaven. In the fourth year *jiashen*, the Venerable Lord descended once more to the Central States, journeying east to Fuduo, where he convened with the Great Thearch and reviewed the assembly of transcendents. He then traveled to the Western Sea, reaching the state of Sulin, where he was styled as the Great Illuminating Envoy, before ascending to Heaven again. Upon hearing that Perfected Yin Xi had attained the Dao and ascended, King Mu had the Louguan Terrace built and established seven Daoist priests to conduct sacrificial rites. This is recorded in the *Inner Transmission of King Mu* and the *Biography of the Master of Louguan*.

In the first year *bingzi* of King Gong’s reign, he ruled for twelve years.
In the first year *wuzi* of King Yi’s reign, he ruled for twenty-five years.
In the first year *guichou* of King Xiao’s reign, he ruled for fifteen years.
In the first year *wuchen* of King Yi’s reign, he ruled for sixteen years.

rane says: "Laozi’s manifestations appear in every generation." The Transcendent Lord Ge states: "Before the opening of creation, he descended as preceptor to the nations, continuing without cease." Wen Shi, Gui Gu, and Zhang Fuhan all declare: "The Venerable Lord existed before the Great Non-Being, traversing Heaven and Earth in ways beyond enumeration." How can these be dismissed as fragmentary writings or the shallow views of later scholars? Ge Hong simply failed to consider this.

King Kang.

chunks.original_text: 老君与玄古三师降于蜀绵竹之三学山，授李真多以飞升之道，今号真多治。 厉王 元年甲申，在位三十六年。 二十一年甲辰，老君降于楼观，授道士宋伦以中景之道、通真之经并灵飞六甲素奏丹符。 周召共和 起庚申，时厉一流于免，太子幼，相和协共理国事十四年。 厉王崩，乃立太子，是为宣王。 宣王 元年甲戌，在位四十七年。 四十三年丙辰，老君降于渭川，告宣王以岁星北迁，言周将衰。 后二年而幽王立。 今渭侧有伯阳川，是其处。 见《地理志》。 时有探薪行歌者，人莫能识，以问老君。 老君日：此活国人，修习无上正真之道也。 唐《历代应见图》。 幽王
chunks.translated_text:
The Lord Lao descended with the Three Masters of Primordial Antiquity upon Three Learning Mountain in Mianzhu of Shu, where he transmitted to Li Duozhen the Dao of ascending in flight. Today, this site is called the Governance of Duozhen.

King Li:
In the first year *jiashen*, he ruled for thirty-six years.
In the twenty-first year *jiachen*, the Lord Lao descended upon Louguan, where he transmitted to the Daoist priest Song Lun the Dao of the Middle Effulgence, the *Scripture of Communing with the Perfected*, and the *Six Jia Talismans of Numinous Flight* inscribed on plain silk.

Duke Zhou and Duke Shao’s Regency:
Beginning in *gengshen*, when King Li was exiled to Zhi, the crown prince being young, the two dukes jointly administered state affairs for fourteen years.
Upon King Li’s death, the crown prince was enthroned as King Xuan.

King Xuan:
In the first year *jiaxu*, he ruled for forty-seven years.
In the forty-third year *bingchen*, the Lord Lao descended upon the Wei River, where he informed King Xuan that Jupiter had shifted northward, foretelling the decline of Zhou.
Two years later, King You ascended the throne.
Beside the Wei River lies Boyang Plain, the site of this event, as recorded in the *Treatise on Geography*.

At that time, there was a firewood-gatherer who walked singing, unknown to all. When asked about him, the Lord Lao said: “This is one who revives the people of the state, cultivating the supreme, perfectly true Dao.”
See the Tang *Illustrated Responses Through the Ages*.

King You.

chunks.original_text: 元年庚申，在位一十一年。 第二年辛酉地动，泾、渭、洛皆震，老君言周将亡矣，不及十年，数之纪也。 后果为犬戎所灭。 出《史记》。 平王 元年辛未，在位五十一年，东迁洛邑。 三十三年癸卯十二月，老君复出关，开化诸国。 遂至西海流、麟等洲，考校群仙。 事讫复还中国。 出《西升经》。 威王 元年壬戌，在位三十三年。 庄王 元年乙酉，在位一十五年。 九年癸巳四月建卯初七日夜，释迦佛生。 释氏《瑞应经》云：四月八日夜半生。 此用周正也。 又《过去见在经》云：二月八日生。 此用夏正也。 老君时年六百一十四岁。 释迦生於周庄王九年，乃《春秋》鲁庄公之七年，当夏四月，常星不见，夜明是也。 至魏武定八年，凡一千二百三十七年云。 出《魏书释老志》及《隋书经籍志》。 《头陀寺碑》云：周、鲁二庄，亲昭夜景之鉴。 见梁昭明太子《文选》齐王巾作。 梁邵陵王上表云：常星不见，周镒娠征，满月圆姿，汉感宵梦。 见唐僧《法苑珠林》。 僖王
chunks.translated_text:
In the first year *gengshen*, he reigned for eleven years.
In the second year *xinyou*, the earth quaked; the Jing, Wei, and Luo Rivers all trembled. The Lord Lao declared that Zhou would perish, and within ten years, the appointed cycle would be fulfilled.
Later, it indeed fell to the Quanrong.
Recorded in the *Records of the Grand Historian*.

King Ping:
In the first year *xinwei*, he reigned for fifty-one years, relocating eastward to Luoyi.
In the thirty-third year *guimao*, in the twelfth month, the Lord Lao once more emerged from the Pass, enlightening the various states.
He then journeyed to the Western Sea’s Liu and Lin Isles, where he examined and ranked the multitude of immortals.
Upon completing his affairs, he returned to the Central Kingdom.
Recorded in the *Scripture of Western Ascension*.

King Wei:
In the first year *renxu*, he reigned for thirty-three years.

King Zhuang:
In the first year *yiyou*, he reigned for fifteen years.
In the ninth year *guisi*, on the seventh day of the fourth month (the first *mao* day of the lunar cycle), the Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
The Buddhist *Sutra of Auspicious Responses* states: he was born at midnight on the eighth day of the fourth month.
This follows the Zhou calendar.
The *Sutra of Past and Present* further states: he was born on the eighth day of the second month.
This follows the Xia calendar.
At that time, the Lord Lao was six hundred and fourteen years old.
The Buddha’s birth in the ninth year of King Zhuang of Zhou corresponds to the seventh year of Duke Zhuang of Lu in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, falling in the fourth month of the Xia calendar, when the fixed stars were not visible and the night shone bright.
By the eighth year of Emperor Wu of Wei’s Wuding era, one thousand two hundred and thirty-seven years had passed.
Recorded in the *Wei Shu’s Treatise on Buddhism and Daoism* and the *Sui Shu’s Bibliographical Treatise*.
The *Stele of the Toutuo Temple* states: “The two Zhuangs of Zhou and Lu personally witnessed the mirror of night’s radiance.”
Cited in Xiao Tong’s *Wen Xuan*, in Qi Wang Jin’s composition.
The Prince of Shaoling of Liang, in his memorial, wrote: “When the fixed stars vanished, Zhou’s jade was pregnant with omens; at the full moon, her form was round—Han’s dream of the night was stirred.”
Cited in the Tang monk’s *Forest of Gems in the Garden of Dharma*.

King Xi.

chunks.original_text: 元年庚子，在位五年。 惠王 元年乙巳，在位二十五年。 襄王 元年庚午，在位三十三年。 项王 元年癸卯，在位六年。 匡王 元年己酉，在位六年。 四年壬子，佛入涅盘。 释氏《金光明经》云：寿命短促，方八十岁是也。 定王 元年乙卯，在位二十一年。 王问老君以在世神仙，老君对以中岳有古先生，即予是也。 出望祠宫张僧鉴、《浔阳记》。 简王 元年丙子，在位一十四年。 灵王 元年庚寅，在位二十七年。 二十一年庚戌十月二十一日，孔子生。 景王元年丁巳，在位二十五年。 悼王立五月。 敬王元年壬午，在位四十三年。 十七年戊戌，孔子谓南官敬叔日：吾闻老聘博古该今，通礼乐之原，明道德之归，则吾师也。 今将往矣。 明年遂与敬叔俱至周，见老子。 按《庄子》云：孔子行年五十，乃南之沛，见老子。 计是此年也。 其问礼及藏书等事，虽见《礼记》、《孔子家语》及《史记》而皆不系年月，故莫知其先后也。 然《家语》所载子夏问於孔子日：商闻易之生人及．万物，各有奇偶，气分不同，惟达德者能原其本也。 天一地二人三，三三为九，九九八十一，一主日，月数十，故人十月而生。 八九七十二，偶以从奇。 奇主辰，辰为月，月主马，故马十二月而生。 其余各从其类也。 鸟鱼生阴而属阳，故皆卯生。 鱼进於水，乌游於云。 故立冬燕雀入海化为蛤介，鳞夏食而冬势，此吞者八窍而卯生，龃齲者九窍而胎生，四足者无羽翼，戴角者无上齿，昼生类父，夜生类母，敢问其然乎。 孔子日：然吾昔闻之老耻，亦如所言。 由此观之，则孔子谓老耻博古该今，故无所不就学焉，何止问礼及五行五帝而已乎。 四十一年建壬戌，孔子卒。 见《孔子家语》及《左氏传》。 老子时年八百二十四岁。 北王 元年乙丑，在位八年。 正定王 元年癸酉，在位二十八年。 －表王 立三月。 · 思王 立五月。 考王 元年辛丑，在位一十五年。 威烈王 元年丙辰，在位二十四年。 安王 元年庚辰，在位二十六年。 十八年丁酉，秦献公立。 夷烈王 元年丙午，在位七年。 二年丁未，老君还秦。 秦献公授馆政礼，问於历数，老君遂出散关。 出《史记》。 显王

In the first year Gengzi, he reigned for five years.

King Hui’s first year Yisi, he reigned for twenty-five years.
King Xiang’s first year Gengwu, he reigned for thirty-three years.
King Xiang’s first year Guimao, he reigned for six years.
King Kuang’s first year Jiyou, he reigned for six years.
In the fourth year Renzi, the Buddha entered *nirvana*.
The Buddhist *Golden Light Sutra* states: “His lifespan was brief, only eighty years.”

King Ding’s first year Yimao, he reigned for twenty-one years.
The king inquired of Lord Lao about the immortals in the world, and Lord Lao replied: “On the Central Peak there is an Ancient Master—it is I.”
Recorded in Zhang Sengjian’s *Wangci Palace* and the *Xunyang Record*.

King Jian’s first year Bingzi, he reigned for fourteen years.
King Ling’s first year Gengyin, he reigned for twenty-seven years.
In the twenty-first year Gengxu, on the twenty-first day of the tenth month, Confucius was born.

King Jing’s first year Dingsi, he reigned for twenty-five years.
King Dao reigned for five months.

King Jing’s first year Renwu, he reigned for forty-three years.
In the seventeenth year Wuxu, Confucius said to Nangong Jingshu: “I have heard that Lao Dan is profoundly versed in antiquity and the present, understands the origins of ritual and music, and illuminates the return of the Dao and virtue—he is my teacher. Now I shall go to him.”
The following year, he and Jingshu together went to Zhou and met Laozi.
According to the *Zhuangzi*: “When Confucius was fifty, he journeyed south to Pei and saw Laozi.” This must refer to this year.
As for his inquiries on ritual and the matter of the archived texts, though recorded in the *Record of Rites*, *The Family Sayings of Confucius*, and the *Records of the Grand Historian*, none specify the year or month, so their sequence remains unknown.
Yet in *The Family Sayings of Confucius*, Zixia asked Confucius: “I have heard that in the *Book of Changes*, the generation of humans and the myriad things each has its odd and even, their qi divided differently. Only those who attain virtue can trace their origins. Heaven is one, earth is two, and man is three; three threes make nine, and nine nines eighty-one. One governs the sun, and the moon’s number is ten, so humans are born after ten months. Eight nines are seventy-two, paired to follow the odd. The odd governs the celestial stems, the stems govern the moon, and the moon governs the horse, so horses are born after twelve months. The rest follow their kind. Birds and fish are born of yin yet belong to yang, so all are born at *mao*. Fish advance in water, birds soar in clouds. Thus at the onset of winter, swallows and sparrows enter the sea and transform into clams and shellfish; scales feed in summer and hibernate in winter. Those that swallow have eight orifices and are born at *mao*, while those that chew have nine orifices and are born from the womb. Four-footed creatures lack feathers and wings; those with horns lack upper teeth. Those born by day resemble their fathers, those born by night their mothers. May I ask if this is so?”
Confucius replied: “Yes, I once heard this from Lao Dan, just as you have said.”
From this, we see that Confucius regarded Lao Dan as profoundly versed in antiquity and the present, so he sought instruction in all things—how could it have been only ritual and the Five Phases or the Five Emperors?
In the forty-first year Jianrenxu, Confucius died.
Recorded in *The Family Sayings of Confucius* and the *Zuo Tradition*.
At that time, Laozi was eight hundred and twenty-four years old.

King Yuan’s first year Yichou, he reigned for eight years.
King Zhengding’s first year Guiyou, he reigned for twenty-eight years.
King Ai reigned for three months.
King Si reigned for five months.

King Kao’s first year Xinchou, he reigned for fifteen years.
King Weilie’s first year Bingchen, he reigned for twenty-four years.
King An’s first year Gengchen, he reigned for twenty-six years.
In the eighteenth year Dingyou, Duke Xian of Qin ascended the throne.

King Yilie’s first year Bingwu, he reigned for seven years.
In the second year Dingwei, Lord Lao returned to Qin.
Duke Xian of Qin received him with lodging and rites, inquiring about the reckoning of time, whereupon Lord Lao departed through the Hangu Pass.
Recorded in the *Records of the Grand Historian*.

King Xian.

chunks.original_text: 元年癸丑，在位四十八年。 八年庚申，秦孝公立。 老君束还，游赤城、蒙山，重过扶朵，较集群仙。 已而隐于景山、太室、少室。 出王子年《拾遗记》。 慎观王 元年癸丑，在位六年。 赧王 迁都西周，元年丁未，五十九年乙巳，尽献其邑於秦，西周遂亡。 九年乙卯，秦昭王立。 老君与尹喜诸仙西游女几、鹞头、天柱，复出散关，遂升昆仑，还紫微上官。 昭王闻之，乃於老君所经游处为置城邑，以表圣迹，故立老君停驿、尹喜城。 馑按《老君本记》并诸史传记并云：老子以商武丁庚辰生於亳，寻乘白鹿而升天。 后一百八年帝辛丁卯，降于岐周。 今以长历推之，武丁元年壬申九年即庚辰也。 传记云：老君以周文王时为守藏史，武王时迁柱下史。 推武王以癸酉□受□□商自武丁庚辰至此癸酉，几一百七十四年也。 传记云：老子以周昭王癸丑五月壬午将去周，七月十二日到函谷关，度尹喜。 推昭王元年辛卯，二十三年癸酉，自癸酉至癸丑，几一百有一年，通前几二百七十四年，乃西度也。 传记云：老子甲寅年四月，於楼观升入太微。 次年乙卯，分身生於蜀。 后二年丁巳，与尹喜会於青羊之肆，遂同往西域。 至穆王元年，复还中夏，束过扶桑大帝之所，较集群仙。 自昭王二十三年癸丑，至穆王元年辛巳，几二十八年，则老君化胡讫，复还中夏之时也。 《史记》云：周幽王二年辛酉，三川震，老子言周铃亡。 自穆王辛巳至此辛酉，几二百二十年，通前几五百二十二年也。 平王二十三年癸卯，老君复出关，游西海，较集诸仙。 《魏书释老志》云：释迦生时当周庄王九年，《春秋》鲁庄公七年四月辛卯，常星不见是也。 按庄王元年乙酉，即九年癸巳也。 自幽王辛酉至此癸巳，九十二年，通前几六百一十四年，而后佛生，至匡王四年壬子入灭。 周灵王二十一年庚戌冬十月二十一日庚子，孔子生。 自庄王癸巳至此庚戌，几一百三十七年，通前几七百五十一年也。 景王十五年辛未，南官敬叔生，时孔子年三十五岁。 敬王十一年壬辰，鲁定公即位，始命敬叔为大夫，辞以先人．遗命使事孔子。 至定公七年戊戌，孔子年五十，乃南之沛，见老子。 即老君应化诸方讫，复还中夏之时也。 自灵王庚戌至此戊戌，几四十九年，通前几七百九十九年也。 传记云：秦昭王闻老子过，为散关修城邑。 据昭王立五十一年乃灭周，推周赧王元年丁未、九年乙卯，乃秦昭王即位之岁，是时老君将升於昆仑还紫微之时也。 自敬王戊戌至此乙卯，几一百九十七年，通前计九百九十六年也。 老君应感无方，变化莫测，或升或降，莫能究悉。 今考传记并长历，推计自商武丁庚辰至周赧王乙卯，几出入隐显绵历九百九十六年，在商一百七十四年，在周八百二十二年，正与史传及诸经典相符。 魏明帝赞云：为周柱史，经九百年。 唐大学博士吴杨昊亦云：老君变通，灵应难测，既生商日，又仕周时，计其始终，乃立千载。 此皆举其成数也。 《史记》称或百六十岁，或云二百岁者，是据孔子时人斟酌老子之岁数云尔，不能知其实，是以每事言盖言或也。 又《列仙传》云：去入大秦。 又云：与尹喜俱游流沙，莫知所终。 皇甫谧云：西之流沙，作《浮屠经》以化戎俗。

The first year Gui-chou, he reigned for forty-eight years.
In the eighth year Geng-shen, Duke Xiao of Qin ascended the throne.
Lord Lao returned eastward, traveling to Red City and Mount Meng, passing again through Fu-duo, where he gathered and assembled the host of immortals.
Thereafter, he concealed himself on Mount Jing, Mount Tai-shi, and Mount Shao-shi.
Recorded in Wang Jia’s *Shi Yi Ji*.

King Shenjing
The first year Gui-chou, he reigned for six years.

King Nan
Having moved the capital to Western Zhou, the first year Ding-wei, and in the fifty-ninth year Yi-si, he ceded all his cities to Qin, whereupon Western Zhou perished.
In the ninth year Yi-mao, King Zhao of Qin ascended the throne.
Lord Lao, together with Yin Xi and the host of immortals, journeyed west to Mount Nü-ji, Mount Yao-tou, and Mount Tian-zhu, then exited once more through the Hangu Pass, ascending Kunlun and returning to the Purple Tenuity’s Upper Palace.
Upon hearing of this, King Zhao ordered cities and towns built at the places Lord Lao had traversed, to mark his sacred traces, thus establishing the lodging station of Lord Lao and the city of Yin Xi.

According to the *Basic Records of Lord Lao* and various historical accounts, Laozi was born in the year Geng-chen of King Wu Ding of Shang at Bo, and soon thereafter ascended to heaven riding a white deer.
One hundred and eight years later, in the year Ding-mao of King Zhou Xin, he descended at Qi Zhou.
Now, reckoning by the extended calendar, the first year of Wu Ding was Ren-shen, and his ninth year was indeed Geng-chen.
The records state: Lord Lao served as Archivist of the Royal Treasury during the time of King Wen of Zhou, and as Archivist Beneath the Pillars during the time of King Wu.
Counting from Wu Ding’s Geng-chen to King Wu’s Gui-you □□□□, nearly one hundred seventy-four years have passed.
The records state: In the fifth month, Ren-wu, of the Gui-chou year of King Zhao of Zhou, Lord Lao was about to leave Zhou, and on the twelfth day of the seventh month, he arrived at the Hangu Pass, where he instructed Yin Xi.
Counting from the first year Xin-mao of King Zhao to his twenty-third year Gui-you, and from Gui-you to Gui-chou, nearly one hundred and one years have passed, totaling nearly two hundred seventy-four years before his westward departure.
The records state: In the year Jia-yin, in the fourth month, Lord Lao ascended into the Great Subtlety at Louguan.
The following year, Yi-mao, he divided his body and was born in Shu.
Two years later, Ding-si, he met Yin Xi at the market of the Green Ram, and together they journeyed to the Western Regions.
By the first year Xin-si of King Mu, he had returned to the Central Lands, passing eastward through the place of the Great Emperor of Fusang, where he gathered and assembled the host of immortals.
From the twenty-third year Gui-chou of King Zhao to the first year Xin-si of King Mu, nearly twenty-eight years have passed, marking the time when Lord Lao had completed his transformation of the Hu and returned to the Central Lands.
The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: In the second year Xin-you of King You of Zhou, the Three Rivers quaked, and Laozi said that Zhou’s mandate was exhausted.
From King Mu’s Xin-si to this Xin-you, nearly two hundred twenty years have passed, totaling nearly five hundred twenty-two years.
In the twenty-third year Gui-mao of King Ping, Lord Lao once more exited the pass, journeyed to the Western Sea, and gathered the host of immortals.
The *Wei Shu: Treatise on Buddhism and Daoism* states: The birth of Śākyamuni occurred in the ninth year of King Zhuang of Zhou, corresponding to the seventh year of Duke Zhuang of Lu in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, the fourth month, Xin-mao, when the constant stars were not seen.
Now, the first year of King Zhuang was Yi-you, and his ninth year was indeed Gui-si.
From King You’s Xin-you to this Gui-si, ninety-two years have passed, totaling nearly six hundred fourteen years before the Buddha’s birth, and he entered nirvāṇa in the fourth year Ren-zi of King Kuang.
Confucius was born on the twenty-first day of the tenth month, Geng-zi, in the twenty-first year Geng-xu of King Ling of Zhou.
From King Zhuang’s Gui-si to this Geng-xu, nearly one hundred thirty-seven years have passed, totaling nearly seven hundred fifty-one years.
In the fifteenth year Xin-wei of King Jing, Nangong Jing-shu was born, when Confucius was thirty-five years old.
In the eleventh year Ren-chen of King Jing, Duke Ding of Lu ascended the throne, and Jing-shu was first appointed as a grandee but declined, citing his ancestor’s command to serve Confucius.
By the seventh year Wu-xu of Duke Ding, when Confucius was fifty years old, he journeyed south to Pei and met Laozi.
This was the time when Lord Lao had completed his manifestations in all directions and returned once more to the Central Lands.
From King Ling’s Geng-xu to this Wu-xu, nearly forty-nine years have passed, totaling nearly seven hundred ninety-nine years.
The records state: Upon hearing that Laozi had passed by, King Zhao of Qin ordered cities and towns built at the Hangu Pass.
According to King Zhao’s fifty-first year, when he destroyed Zhou, reckoning from the first year Ding-wei of King Nan of Zhou and his ninth year Yi-mao, when King Zhao of Qin ascended the throne, this was the time when Lord Lao was about to ascend Kunlun and return to the Purple Tenuity’s Upper Palace.
From King Jing’s Wu-xu to this Yi-mao, nearly one hundred ninety-seven years have passed, totaling nearly nine hundred ninety-six years.
Lord Lao’s responses were boundless, his transformations unfathomable; whether ascending or descending, none could fully comprehend.
Now, examining the records and the extended calendar, reckoning from Wu Ding’s Geng-chen of Shang to Yi-mao of King Nan of Zhou, spanning appearances and concealments over nearly nine hundred ninety-six years—one hundred seventy-four years in Shang and eight hundred twenty-two years in Zhou—this aligns precisely with historical accounts and various classics.
Emperor Ming of Wei praised: "As Archivist Beneath the Pillars of Zhou, he endured nine hundred years."
Wu Yanghao, Academician of the Tang Imperial University, also said: "Lord Lao’s transformations and numinous responses are difficult to fathom; born in the days of Shang, he also served in the time of Zhou, and reckoning from beginning to end, he stood for a thousand years."
These all refer to round numbers.
The *Records of the Grand Historian* mentions "perhaps one hundred sixty years" or "perhaps two hundred years," which is based on the estimations of people in Confucius’ time regarding Laozi’s age, unable to know the truth, hence the frequent use of "perhaps" or "maybe."
Moreover, the *Lie Xian Zhuan* states: "He departed and entered Da Qin."
It also states: "Together with Yin Xi, he journeyed to the Flowing Sands, and none knew where they ultimately went."
Huangfu Mi said: "He went west to the Flowing Sands and composed the *Futu Jing* to transform the Rong customs."

chunks.original_text: 《文始内传》云：老子出关，周游八十一国，后至属宾化胡。 刘向赞日：德合元熙，寿同两仪。 据诸传记说虽不同，莫不赞其长寿，盖儒者以长生升天之说为怪诞，故但云莫知所终，说其未尝死也。 唐尹文操论云：老君乃积劫得道之大圣人也，故能寄惠人间，和光幽显，千变万化，今古常存。 惟庄子假设秦失参号之说，将以逆荡几浅执生者耳。 而梁武帝遂以老君为尸解之仙，谬矣。 遍寻老子始终，竟无解蜕之进，而庄周独云尔者，亦犹云将、鸿蒙之类，并傲史之寓言。 若以为实，则孔子见盗坏亦可为实事耶。 按王子年《拾遗记》云：老子至周之末，居于景室之山，尝云我常在人问，不去须央。 或为凡，或为圣，但流俗之人不知之。 人行善恶，各有罪福，如影之随形，响之应声，若能思真念善，自可与我相遇。 以此详之，尤明其不死审矣。 又按《龙踏经》云：老子於大罗天明霞观中告九天丈人日：吾今应相，境界通身，上显诸天，下应万象，历劫演化，开度兆人，有道上贤，降为师授，或生下界，与物混冥，托质通凡，浮况莫辫，与道通化，应接有缘，潜行救度，不恃有恩。 既其神通自在，世世随机降应，何生死之能累乎。 儿曹以管窥天，果不足怪。 或云老子受学於容城，或问道於常枞，此盖至人好贤乐善，以多问寡，亦将造端於师资以垂世立教耳，岂真有所授受耶。 旧传记其子孙显仕继世不绝者，此又至人不欲索隐行怪以惊世骇俗，故示幻进以和光同尘耳。 今虑后世贵纵之夫，认幻为真而托道为奸者，将授以藉口，故皆删之。 至十六变之说，事述隐晦，亦无迷焉。 秦始皇帝 元年乙卯，在位三十六年，庚辰初并天下为皇帝。 二十八年壬午，封禅泰山，乃建老君祠於楼观之南，躬行飨祀。 老君降于祠，授帝以《鬼林经》策使鬼神之符。 出《楼观传》。 前汉文帝
chunks.translated_text:
*The Inner Transmission of the Primordial Beginning* states: After Laozi departed through the pass, he journeyed through eighty-one kingdoms and later arrived in Jibin to transform the Hu peoples.

Liu Xiang’s eulogy reads: His virtue harmonized with the Primordial Radiance, his longevity matched the Two Modes.

Though the various traditions differ in their accounts, none fail to extol his long life. Confucians, however, deem the notion of ascending to heaven through longevity as absurd, and thus merely state that none knew his end, implying he never truly died.

Tang scholar Yin Wencao argued: Lao Jun was a great sage who attained the Dao through kalpas of cultivation, and thus could bestow blessings upon the world, harmonizing the hidden and the manifest, undergoing myriad transformations while remaining eternally present. Only Zhuangzi, through the fictional dialogue of Qin Shi’s lament, sought to unsettle those of shallow understanding who cling to life. Yet Emperor Wu of Liang mistakenly took Lao Jun for a corpse-liberated immortal—this was a grave error.

Upon thorough examination of Laozi’s life from beginning to end, no evidence of a release-by-death is found. Zhuang Zhou’s lone assertion is akin to his fables of Jiang and Hong Meng—mere allegories of defiance against history. To take them as fact would be as absurd as accepting Confucius’ encounter with Robber Zhi as a true event.

According to Wang Jia’s *Records of Forgotten Lore*: In the late Zhou, Laozi dwelled on Mount Jingshi, often declaring, “I am ever among men, never absent for even a moment. At times I appear as an ordinary person, at others as a sage—only the vulgar fail to recognize me. Men’s good and evil deeds each bear their karmic consequences, like shadows following form or echoes answering sound. Those who contemplate truth and aspire to goodness may yet encounter me.” This further confirms his undying nature.

The *Scripture of the Dragon’s Hoof* records: In the Hall of Bright Clouds within the Great Luo Heaven, Laozi addressed the Celestial Venerable of the Nine Heavens, saying: “Now, in response to karmic conditions, my realm pervades my entire being, manifesting above in the heavens and below in the myriad phenomena. Through kalpas of transformation, I guide and deliver countless beings. The worthy and the sagely of the Dao descend to become their teachers, or are born into the lower realms, mingling indistinguishably with the worldly, assuming mortal forms yet remaining untainted by the mundane. In harmony with the Dao, I respond to those with affinity, silently aiding and delivering them, never claiming merit. Since my spiritual power is self-so, I descend in every age to meet the needs of the time—how could birth and death ever bind me? You, my disciples, peer at the heavens through a tube—no wonder you find it strange.”

Some claim Laozi studied under Rongcheng or sought the Dao from Chang Cong. This merely reflects the sagely one’s love of worthies and joy in goodness, his humility in seeking knowledge from others. It was also a means to establish the teacher-disciple tradition for posterity—how could there have been any true transmission of teachings?

Older traditions record that his descendants held prominent offices in unbroken succession. This, too, was the sage’s way of avoiding reclusion and eccentricity to startle the world, instead manifesting illusions to harmonize with the dust of the world. Yet fearing that later generations of arrogant and dissolute men might mistake illusion for reality and use the Dao as a pretext for villainy, I have excised such accounts.

As for the theory of the Sixteen Transformations, its details are obscure and offer no enlightenment.

In the first year of Emperor Qin Shi Huang, the yimao year (246 BCE), he reigned for thirty-six years, and in the gengchen year (221 BCE), he first unified the realm as emperor. In the twenty-eighth year, renwu (219 BCE), he performed the Feng and Shan sacrifices on Mount Tai and established a shrine to Lao Jun south of the Louguan Temple, personally conducting the rites. Lao Jun descended to the shrine and bestowed upon the emperor the *Ghostly Forest Scripture*, a talisman for commanding spirits and deities.

—From the *Louguan Tradition*

chunks.original_text: 永建元年丙寅，后六年改元阳嘉，又四年丙子改永和，又六年壬午改汉安，又二年甲申改建康。 汉安元年壬午，老君降于蜀之鹤呜山，授天师张道陵《正一盟威秘录》。 五月再降，赐《秦清中经》九百三十卷、符文七十卷。 建康元年甲申，老君再降于阂州云台山，授天师三洞众经及超度九祖斋直之法。 见《天师传》及《蜀图经》 桓帝 建和元年丁亥，后三年庚寅改和平，又一年辛卯改元嘉，又二年癸巳改永兴，又二年乙未改永寿，又三年戊戌改延熹，又九年丁未改永康。 水寿元年乙未，老君降于成都，授天师北斗削死注生之法。 今成都府玉局化即其地。 又降于鹿堂山，授以制六天斩邪文。 见《天师传》及《蜀图经》。 延熹八年，帝遣使诣陈祀老君，命边韶撰碑文，九年，帝亲祀老君於濯龙官，用郊天乐。 并见《后汉记》。 灵帝

chunks.original_text: 永徽元年庚戌，后七年丙辰改元显庆，又五年辛酉改元龙朔，又三年甲子改元麟德，又二年丙寅改元乾封，又二年戊辰改元总章，又二年庚午改元咸亨，又四年甲戌改元上元，又二年丙子改元仪凤，又三年己卯改元调露，又一年庚辰改元永隆，又一年辛巳改元开耀，又一年壬午改元永淳。 龙朔二年壬戌，帝幸洛阳官，建清庙於北邓治，以祠老君，设醮庆赞。 老君降于殿上，二真人夹侍，光耀阶坛，众咸瞻仰。 官闱令权大力等列状奏闻，照依所见图写为瑞像。 见《洛阳录事》杨护师奏状。 乾封元年丙寅，帝封岱岳，驾至亳，朝谒老君，御制册文，上尊号日玄元皇帝，圣母为先天太后。 出《唐书》。 仪凤三年戊寅，帝敕建斋於阳清庙。 时老君降于坛上，祥光照映，乘白马，履坛石，皆有迹，众所瞻仰，登时奏闻。 贺表云：金相玉毫，彩夺夜明之景。 白驹丹鬣，迹留天驷之诞。 见朝散大夫孙瑞奏状。 则天武后

chunks.original_text: 嗣圣元年甲申，二月改元文明，九月又改光宅。 摄位二十二年，乙巳改元神龙，元一十八年。 文明元年甲申。 ，老君降于号州皇天原，命鄗元宗，令传言武后，不可草命。 出《唐书》。 景龙四年庚戌，为平内难疑央，老君为白衣老父，卖卦於春明门外。 象日：宜取天下，吉。 利在三日内。 后於其处立庙。 出《洛中记异》。 玄宗明皇 开元元年癸丑。 后二十九年壬午改元天宝，又三年甲申改年为载。 开元十七年，老君降于蜀州新兴寺，隐景於佛殿柱中，宛如刻画，削洗愈现。 本路文武官及道、僧、俗、尼同状奏闻，有云：现於殿柱，杳疑作史之年。 服彼佛祠，缅若化胡之日。 见於益州长史张敬中奏状表。 开元二十九年，老君降于丹凤门外，语田同秀日：我昔日入流沙，藏一金灵符在尹喜旧宅，可奏帝取之。 帝遣使求得之於函谷关故墟。 出《唐书》。 天宝二年癸未正月，上老君尊号日大圣祖玄元皇帝。 十二月，帝幸华清官，老君降现于朝元阁上，遂改朝元阁为降圣阁。 见《唐史》。 天宝七载戊子，上老君尊号日圣祖大道玄元皇帝。 九载庚寅，老君降于太白山，语山人王玄翼以宝仙洞有妙宝真符。 上命刑部尚书王唾等往求，果得之。 出《唐书》。 十三载甲午二月癸酉，帝朝献太清官，加上老君尊号日大圣祖高上大道金阙玄天元皇大帝。 出《唐书》。 十五载丙申，．帝幸蜀，老君降于汉中郡黑水之侧。 帝命刻石像於所见之处。 又乘白鹿降于利州昌岭上，以示收山之兆。 诏於所现之处立自然观。 并出《唐书》。 肃宗

In the first year of Tisheng (684 CE), the jiashen year, the second month saw the era name changed to Wenming, and the ninth month to Guangzhai. After twenty-two years of regency, in the yisi year (705 CE), the era name was changed to Shenlong, lasting eighteen years in total.

In the first year of Wenming (684 CE), the jiashen year, Lao Jun descended upon Huangtian Plain in Haozhou, commanding Hao Yuanzong to convey to Empress Wu that she must not usurp the Mandate of Heaven. Recorded in the *Annals of Tang*.

In the fourth year of Jinglong (710 CE), the gengxu year, to resolve doubts during the pacification of internal strife, Lao Jun appeared as a white-robed elder selling divinations outside the Chunming Gate. His oracle read: "It is auspicious to seize the realm; the advantage lies within three days." Later, a temple was erected at the site. Recorded in *Strange Tales of Luozhong*.

**Emperor Xuanzong of Tang (Minghuang)**

In the first year of Kaiyuan (713 CE), the guichou year, twenty-nine years later, in the renwu year (742 CE), the era name was changed to Tianbao, and three years after that, in the jiashen year (744 CE), the term for the year was altered to *zai*.

In the seventeenth year of Kaiyuan (729 CE), Lao Jun descended upon Xinxing Temple in Shuzhou, his hidden radiance manifesting within a pillar of the Buddha hall, as vivid as if carved or painted—scrubbing and washing only made it clearer. Local civil and military officials, along with Daoists, monks, laypeople, and nuns, jointly memorialized the event, stating: "Appearing upon the hall’s pillar, its traces evoke the era of the historian’s craft. Dwelling within the Buddha’s shrine, it recalls the distant days of the *Huahu* transformation." Recorded in the memorial of Prefectural Governor of Yizhou, Zhang Jingzhong.

In the twenty-ninth year of Kaiyuan (741 CE), Lao Jun descended outside the Danfeng Gate, speaking to Tian Tongxiu: "Long ago, I entered the Flowing Sands and concealed a golden numinous talisman in Yin Xi’s former residence. Memorialize the Emperor to retrieve it." The Emperor dispatched envoys, who recovered it from the ruins of the Hangu Pass. Recorded in the *Annals of Tang*.

In the second year of Tianbao (743 CE), the guimao year, the first month, the Emperor bestowed upon Lao Jun the honorific *Great Sage Ancestor Mysterious Origin Emperor*. In the twelfth month, as the Emperor visited the Huaqing Palace, Lao Jun descended and appeared above the Chaoyuan Pavilion, prompting the Emperor to rename it the *Jiangsheng Pavilion* ("Pavilion of the Descended Sage"). Recorded in the *Annals of Tang*.

In the seventh year of Tianbao (748 CE), the wuzi year, the Emperor bestowed upon Lao Jun the honorific *Sage Ancestor Great Dao Mysterious Origin Emperor*. In the ninth year (750 CE), the gengyin year, Lao Jun descended upon Mount Taibai, telling the mountain dweller Wang Xuanyi that the Baoxian Grotto held a wondrous treasure and true talisman. The Emperor commanded Minister of Justice Wang Qi and others to seek it, and they indeed obtained it. Recorded in the *Annals of Tang*.

In the thirteenth year of Tianbao (754 CE), the jiayin year, on the guimao day of the second month, the Emperor performed sacrifices at the Taiqing Palace and added to Lao Jun’s honorific: *Great Sage Ancestor Supreme Great Dao Golden Portal Mysterious Heaven Origin Emperor*. Recorded in the *Annals of Tang*.

In the fifteenth year of Tianbao (756 CE), the bingshen year, as the Emperor fled to Shu, Lao Jun descended beside the Black Waters in Hanzhong Prefecture. The Emperor ordered a stone statue carved at the site of the apparition. Lao Jun also descended upon Changling in Lizhou, riding a white deer, foretelling the omen of reclaiming the mountains. An edict was issued to establish the Ziran Abbey at the site of the manifestation. Both events recorded in the *Annals of Tang*.

**Emperor Suzong**

chunks.original_text: 天宝十五年丙申改元至德，又三年戊戌改乾元，又二年庚子改上元。 至德二年丁酉，老君降于通化郡云龙岩，自地接天，仪相炳然。 诏图其本。 明皇御赞日：昼现珠相，空浮瑞色，道释人天，作礼瞻奉。 申命藻绘，示诸郡国。 见唐《太上皇瑞赞序》。 敬宗 宝历元年乙巳。 宝历二年丙午，老君降于太清官前御路，指示长安县郑剪陷井之处。 见柳公权书韦处厚所撰碑。 懿宗 咸通元年庚辰。 咸通十年己丑，庞勋领三千余人欲劫夺太清官，时士庶数百余家在官避难，咸见老君乘空而行，须臾黑雾昏噎，贼迷路，自相蹂践，庞勋亦溺水死。 见汴州节度李尉奏状。 宋真宗皇帝

Daoists, Buddhists, and beings of heaven and earth

**Emperor Zhenzong of Song**
In the first year of Xiangfu (1008 CE), the wushen year.

In the seventh year of Dazhong Xiangfu (1014 CE), the jiayin year, the imperial carriage journeyed to Bozhou to pay homage at the Taiqing Palace. The emperor personally presented the imperial册宝, bestowing the august title *Supreme Lord Lao, the Primordial Emperor of Supreme Virtue*. Recorded in *Veritable Records of the Song Dynasty*.

**Emperor Huizong of Song**
In the first year of Zhenghe (1111 CE), the xinmao year.

In the second year of Zhenghe (1112 CE), the renchen year, Lord Lao, riding a white horse and borne upon auspicious clouds, descended to the Yuchen Temple on Mount Mao, where he transmitted to Liang Guangying the augmented *Scripture of the Heavenly Youth*. Other manifestations and apparitions unattached to specific eras are not recounted here. As for events such as radiant illuminations, auspicious omens, dream revelations, divine utterances, and miraculous validations—not involving the descent of an incarnate transformation—these too are recorded in the annals.

*Annals of the Primordial Sage, Scroll the First* concludes.

chunks.original_text: 太上老君乃大道之宗祖，三才之本根也。 太极之先，寥廓何有，道源肇启，黑母混成，顺洞瞑滓，兆朕胚晖，中有真精，自然而生，是为神明，强名虚·皇。 潜司玄化，道运御世，一黑分三，为玄元始。 三黑混合，氤氲渐着，为万象之端。 莫知其先，强目曰元，莫知其初，强目日始，故日元始天尊。 三黑相生，九黑混合，化生诸天，成就世界。 莫知其大，强目曰太，莫知其高，强目曰上，首出无极，仰之曰老，宰而无我，主之日君，故曰元上三天玄元始三黑太上老君焉。 初自一黑而分三黑，是为三天。 三黑合生九黑，是为九天。 自大罗天生清微天、禹余天、大赤天三清境也。 自三天下生郁单天、禅善天、须延天、兜衍天、不骄乐天、洞元天、梵辅天、清明天、无想天，此九大梵天也。 九天又各下生三天，合三十六天。 其外诸小梵天，悉系属於此大梵天也。 九黑乃融黑、炎黑、演黑、昊黑、景黑、道黑、混黑、洞黑、浩黑也。 次四种民天， 太极平育天、龙变梵度天、玉隆腾胜天、太虚常融天，为种民天，亦日种人，谓开劫之初降为人种也，释氏呼为四禅天。 此天上取太清境三千三百万亿熙，下生八梵天五千五百五十五万熙，几一熙三千里。 此天出三界之上，超阴阳之数，故无年寿之限，水火风灾所不能坏也。 次分三界， 欲界六天，色界十八天，无色界四天也。 次八梵天， 始青天、青元天、始丹天、太丹天、始素天、太素天、始玄天、太玄天也。 次人问世．。 北方清静世界，束北长安世界，东方纳善世界，束南用贤世界，南方弃贤世界，西南仁静世界，西方净行世界，西北延贤世界。 下置九地，结为山岳，融为海渍。 第一垒润色泽地，第二垒刚泽色地，第三垒脂色泽地，第四垒润泽地，第五垒金粟泽地，第六垒金刚铁泽地，第七垒水制地，第八垒大风泽地，第九垒洞泉无色纲维地。 每垒一重土，一重水，一重风，自上而下也。 阳精为日，阴精为月，分日月五行之精为星辰。 二黑交会，则动植万汇更相产化。 按《开化置品经》日：吾於无形无名蒙顽淇津之中，开道玄黄，分灵散黑，从大罗下生三境，次生九天，立九帝为三宝之玄律，二十七天为境界之修品，三十六部为三境之玄根，下为三十六天之域宅。 次三十二天，三十二帝，潜运开化，下分三界，傍贯漩玑二十八宿，五星缠度以明五方，清黑上腾，重浊下凝。 下生九地，中生九人。 天地人物，无不备焉。 故阳和正熙化生上圣高真，柔和冲静之黑化生元君圣后、仙妃玉女，刚烈英勇之黑化生天丁力士、神一兵将史，阴阳五行之熙化生男女，杂谬之黑化生飞禽走兽。 咸承一无，万种不同，随其化生也。 大劫之末，九地之上至无色界，三灾大作，万象消化。 种民天之上，灾所不及。 元黑复合，再为混沌。 历劫重开，复命天人降为人种，为君为臣，洪道建法，随时布化，o已经无量浩浩之劫，悉皆如是。 按《上清经》云：天圆十二纲，地方十二纪，天纲运关三百六十度为阳孛，地纪推机三千六百度为阴蚀，天纲三百三十日运关一周，地纪三千三百日推机一度。 九千九百度为天地熙交，名大阳九、大百六，亦名大劫大运也。 以数乘之，大几三百三十年一度阳孛，此为小阳九之灾。
chunks.translated_text:
The Most High Lord Lao is the ancestral founder of the Great Dao and the root origin of the Three Powers. Before the Supreme Ultimate, there was only vast emptiness—until the source of the Dao first stirred. The Dark Mother coalesced in primordial chaos, and from the murky depths emerged the first glimmer of embryonic radiance. Within it lay true essence, born of itself, which became spirit and illumination. By force of naming, it was called the Void Sovereign. Concealed, it governed the mysterious transformations; through the Dao’s movement, it ruled the world.

From the One Qi, the Three Qi emerged—these being the Mysterious, the Primordial, and the Origin. When the Three Qi blended, their subtle vapors gradually took form, giving rise to the beginnings of the ten thousand phenomena. None knew what came before, so it was forcibly named *Yuan* ("Origin"); none knew its beginning, so it was forcibly named *Shi* ("Commencement")—hence the title *Yuanshi Tianzun* ("Heavenly Worthy of Primordial Beginning"). As the Three Qi generated one another, the Nine Qi merged, giving birth to the various heavens and completing the worlds. None knew its greatness, so it was forcibly named *Tai* ("Supreme"); none knew its height, so it was forcibly named *Shang* ("Most High"). It stood foremost beyond the Ultimate, and gazing upward, it was called *Lao* ("Ancient"); governing without self, it was called *Jun* ("Lord")—thus was formed the title *Yuanshang Santian Xuanyuan Shi Sanqi Taishang Laojun* ("Most High Lord Lao of the Three Heavens of Primordial Origin, the Three Qi, and the Mysterious Beginning").

Initially, from the One Qi arose the Three Qi, which constitute the Three Heavens. The Three Qi combined to generate the Nine Qi, which constitute the Nine Heavens. From the Great Brahma Heaven descended the Three Pure Realms: the Heaven of Qingwei, the Heaven of Yuyu, and the Heaven of Dachi. Below the Three Heavens arose the nine great Brahma Heavens: Yudan Heaven, Shanshan Heaven, Xuyan Heaven, Douyan Heaven, Bujiaole Heaven, Dongyuan Heaven, Fanfu Heaven, Qingming Heaven, and Wuxiang Heaven. Each of the Nine Heavens further generated three heavens below, totaling thirty-six heavens. All lesser Brahma Heavens beyond these are subordinate to these great Brahma Heavens. The Nine Qi are the Fused Qi, the Blazing Qi, the Evolving Qi, the Vast Qi, the Radiant Qi, the Dao Qi, the Chaotic Qi, the Penetrating Qi, and the Boundless Qi.

Next are the Four Heavens of Seed-Peoples: the Heaven of Supreme Ultimate Peace and Nurturance, the Heaven of Dragon Transformation and Brahma Salvation, the Heaven of Jade Eminence and Ascendant Victory, and the Heaven of Great Emptiness and Constant Fusion. These are the Heavens of Seed-Peoples, also called the Seed-Humans, for at the beginning of each kalpa, they descend to become the progenitors of humanity. The Buddhists refer to them as the Four Dhyāna Heavens. Above, these heavens draw from the Three Thousand Three Hundred Million *xi* of the Three Pure Realms of the Great Clarity; below, they generate the Five Thousand Five Hundred Fifty-Five Million *xi* of the Eight Brahma Heavens. Each *xi* measures three thousand *li*. These heavens lie beyond the Three Realms, transcending the reckonings of yin and yang, and thus are not bound by limits of years or lifespans, nor can they be destroyed by the calamities of water, fire, or wind.

Next are the Three Realms: the Realm of Desire with its six heavens, the Realm of Form with its eighteen heavens, and the Formless Realm with its four heavens. Then come the Eight Brahma Heavens: Beginning Azure Heaven, Azure Origin Heaven, Beginning Cinnabar Heaven, Supreme Cinnabar Heaven, Beginning Plain Heaven, Supreme Plain Heaven, Beginning Mysterious Heaven, and Supreme Mysterious Heaven. Next is the human world, divided into eight directions: the Pure and Tranquil World of the North, the Everlasting Peace World of the Northeast, the Welcoming Virtue World of the East, the Employing Worthies World of the Southeast, the Abandoning Worthies World of the South, the Benevolent and Tranquil World of the Southwest, the Pure Conduct World of the West, and the Extending Worthies World of the Northwest. Below these lie the Nine Earths, which solidify into mountains and merge into seas and marshes.

The First Earth is the Moist and Lustrous Earth; the Second, the Hard and Lustrous Earth; the Third, the Unctuous and Lustrous Earth; the Fourth, the Moist Earth; the Fifth, the Golden Grain Earth; the Sixth, the Diamond and Iron Earth; the Seventh, the Water-Restrained Earth; the Eighth, the Great Wind Earth; and the Ninth, the Penetrating Spring and Colorless Net Earth. Each layer consists of one stratum of soil, one of water, and one of wind, descending from above.

The essence of yang becomes the sun; the essence of yin becomes the moon. The essences of the sun, moon, and Five Phases coalesce into the stars. When the Two Qi interact, the myriad beings of plants and animals mutually generate and transform. As the *Scripture on Establishing the Kalpas* states: "Within the formless and nameless, the turbid and chaotic, I opened the Mysterious Yellow of the Dao, divided the numinous, and dispersed the qi. From the Great Brahma Heaven descended the Three Realms; next arose the Nine Heavens. The Nine Emperors were established as the mysterious laws of the Three Treasures; the twenty-seven heavens became the cultivated realms of the boundaries. The thirty-six departments formed the mysterious roots of the Three Realms, and below, they became the domains of the thirty-six heavens. Next came the thirty-two heavens and thirty-two emperors, who subtly governed the transformations. Below, they divided into the Three Realms, laterally connecting to the revolving mechanism of the twenty-eight constellations. The Five Stars wove their paths to illuminate the five directions. The pure qi ascended; the heavy and turbid congealed below. Below arose the Nine Earths; in the middle arose the Nine Humans. Heaven, earth, and all beings were thus complete.

Thus, the harmonious and upright qi of yang gave birth to the lofty perfected sages; the gentle and tranquil qi of softness gave birth to the Primordial Ladies, sagely consorts, female immortals, and jade maidens; the fierce and valiant qi gave birth to the Heavenly Soldiers, the Divine Generals, and the martial officers; the qi of yin, yang, and the Five Phases gave birth to men and women; and the chaotic and errant qi gave birth to birds and beasts. All derive from the One Non-Being, yet their myriad forms differ according to their generation.

At the end of a great kalpa, from the Nine Earths up to the Formless Realm, the Three Calamities arise, and the ten thousand phenomena dissolve. Above the Heavens of Seed-Peoples, the calamities do not reach. The Primordial Qi recombines, returning to chaos. After the kalpa reopens, the heavenly beings are once more commanded to descend as human seed, becoming rulers and ministers. They propagate the great Dao and establish the laws, disseminating transformations in accordance with the times. Countless vast kalpas have passed, and all have proceeded thus.

As the *Scripture of Supreme Clarity* states: The heavens are round with twelve guiding principles; the earth is square with twelve governing mechanisms. The heavenly principles revolve through three hundred sixty degrees, forming the yang comet; the earthly mechanisms advance through three thousand six hundred degrees, forming the yin eclipse. The heavenly principles complete one revolution in three hundred thirty days; the earthly mechanisms advance one degree in three thousand three hundred days. Nine thousand nine hundred degrees mark the convergence of heaven and earth’s qi, known as the Great Yang Nine and the Great Hundred Six—also called the Great Kalpa and the Great Cycle. Multiplying these numbers, a minor yang comet occurs roughly once every three hundred thirty years, which constitutes the Lesser Yang Nine Calamity.

chunks.original_text: 一百八万九千年即天纲运关，三万三千周地纪推机，三千三百度大运之交也。 夫天动地静，阳躁阴迟，故有孛、蚀之异耳。 此时天气穷於太阴，地气极於太阳，阳极则孛，阴极则否，阳极则其精化为水，阴极则其精化为火。 先焚为大火，次漂以大水，上至九天之下，下至九地之内，金玉消化，毫末无遗，然后元气复合，谓之混沌。 混沌再分，则三天上．圣，四天种民，下世教化，亦如此劫之初，三皇五帝相承而治矣。 如此变革，总名为元熙离合。 老君历此离合之数，经无量劫，故《西升经》云：动则有载劫，自惟甚苦勤。 此之谓也。 《风俗通》曰：十千日万，十万日亿，十亿日兆，十兆日经，十经日垓，十垓日载。 载者谓地不能载也。 又按《九天生神章》日：大运将期，数终甲申，三官鼓笔，料别种人，考算功过，善恶当分。 自赤明以来，至上皇元年，依元阳玉匮受度者，应二十四．万人。 开皇以后，数至甲申，诸天选叔，仙曹空废，官僚不充。 依《元阳玉历》，当依三代，更料有心，积善建功，为三界所举，五帝所保，名在上天者，取十万人以充其任。 又当别举一十二万人，以充储官。 三官相应，皆逆注种名。 谓合生四天为后劫种人也。 又九幽之府，被束华青官九龙符命，使拔九幽男女死魂，宿名有善，功德满足，应受开度者，取三十二万人，以充甲申驱除之后，开大有之民。 劫历皆然，悉察命於老君也。 天地之状，象类鸡卵，元黑绕之，如日之晕。 如是天地有五亿五万五千五百五十五亿重，各於其中立天文地理，运阴阳五行，列神祇，产万汇，秉生成之柄，镇造化之原。 故在天为众圣之尊，在世为万教之主，谓之老子者，道之形也。 应既不一，号亦无量。 或三十六号，或七十二名，或号九天上皇，或号洞真帝一君，或号高上玉帝，或号长生大帝，或号太平正真太乙妙黑皇君，或号九玄帝君，或号太千法王，或号九灵老子，或号太上左玄真人，或号上清金阙三洞妙经大法师，或号高上大法王，或号玄一真定光，或号金阙后圣君，或号九老仙都君，或号九黑丈人，或号太上丈人，或号千二百官君，或号太平上景君，或号无为父，或号万物母。 其降生之时，十方天神空霏戴智、无上尊、帝王师、大丈夫、大仙尊、天人父、无为上人、大慈仁者、真元教主。 天人称赞，亦有十号，曰无为之君、无上玄老、太上老君、高上老子、天皇大帝、玄中大法师、有古大先生、金阙帝君、太上高皇、虚无大真人。 复有至真无极大道、自然元始太上天尊、道君、无上天真、天老、天师、黄老、玄宗、世师、神人、真人、仙人．、至人、大人、道人、圣人之号也。 以上自天真以下号各二字。 老君洞真极圣，本无常形，消则为黑，息则为人。 或於太虚之中凝为真容，体大无边，相好备足，上无所攀，下无所蹑。 或在云华之上，身如金色，万真侍卫，百灵宗奉。 或坐莲花之内，建七曜玲珑之冠，披九色离罗之被，项负圆光，照曜天地。 或处宝堂金殿，珠玉帷帐，万帝朝礼，神兵卫轩。 或金容玉姿，黄裳绣被。 或素服玄冠，乘朱鬃白马。 或下治十天，封掌兆民，居太微、勾陈、紫房中，为天皇大帝。 或春化为上景君，长九千丈，建七精宝华之冠，衣玄黄二黑之服，青锦飞裙，手执虎符，坐七色之云。
chunks.translated_text:
One hundred eighty-nine thousand years mark the completion of the heavenly principles’ revolution, thirty-three thousand cycles of the earthly mechanisms’ advancement, and the convergence of three thousand three hundred degrees of the Great Cycle. As heaven moves and earth remains still, yang is swift while yin is slow—hence the distinction between comets and eclipses. At this time, heavenly qi is exhausted in the Great Yin, and earthly qi reaches its peak in the Great Yang. When yang is at its extreme, comets appear; when yin is at its extreme, stagnation arises. At yang’s extremity, its essence transforms into water; at yin’s extremity, its essence transforms into fire. First, the world is consumed by great fire, then submerged by great floods—rising to the space beneath the Nine Heavens, descending to the depths within the Nine Earths—until gold and jade dissolve, and not even the smallest trace remains. Only then do the primordial qi recombine, known as the Primal Chaos. When the Primal Chaos divides again, the Three Heavens’ sages and the Four Heavens’ seed-people descend to teach and transform the world, just as at the beginning of this kalpa, when the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors succeeded one another in governance. Such transformations are collectively called the Cycles of Convergence and Separation.

The Most Venerable Lord has endured these cycles of separation and convergence through countless kalpas, as the *Scripture of Western Ascension* states: *"Movement brings the burden of kalpas; I reflect on the toil and hardship."* This is what it means.

The *Comprehensive Records of Customs* states: *"Ten thousand days make a wan, ten wan make a yi, ten yi make a zhao, ten zhao make a jing, ten jing make a gai, and ten gai make a zai."* The term *zai* signifies that the earth can no longer bear it.

According to the *Nine Heavens’ Chapters on the Generation of Spirits*: When the Great Cycle nears its end and the count concludes on the year of *jiashen*, the Three Officials wield their brushes to assess and distinguish the seed-people, calculating merits and transgressions to separate the good from the evil. From the era of Red Clarity to the first year of the Supreme Sovereign, those who received initiation according to the *Primordial Yang Jade Treasury* numbered two hundred forty thousand. From the era of Kaihuang to the year of *jiashen*, as the heavens select the worthy, the offices of immortals lie vacant, and the celestial bureaucracy remains unfilled. According to the *Primordial Yang Jade Calendar*, three generations must pass before those of sincere heart, who accumulate goodness and establish merit, are recommended by the Three Realms and protected by the Five Emperors—those whose names are recorded in the heavens—are chosen, ten thousand in number, to fill these roles. An additional one hundred twenty thousand are to be selected as reserve officials. The Three Officials correspond in harmony, inscribing the names of the seed-people in reverse order, for they are destined to be born in the Four Heavens as the people of the next kalpa.

Furthermore, the Nine Dark Prisons receive the Nine Dragon Talismanic Mandate from the Azure Palace of the Eastern Marchmount, commanding the liberation of the male and female souls of the dead in the Nine Dark Prisons—those whose past lives bore good names, whose merits and virtues are complete, and who are destined to receive deliverance. Thirty-two thousand such souls are chosen to replenish the people of the Great Prosperity after the purgation of *jiashen*. All kalpas follow this pattern, with destinies scrutinized by the Most Venerable Lord.

The form of heaven and earth resembles that of a chicken’s egg, encircled by primordial darkness like the halo around the sun. Thus, there are five hundred five million five hundred fifty-five myriad layers of heaven and earth, each containing its own celestial patterns and terrestrial principles, circulating yin and yang and the Five Phases, arraying gods and spirits, generating the myriad things, wielding the handle of life and completion, and anchoring the origin of creation and transformation. Therefore, in the heavens, he is the most revered among all sages; in the world, he is the master of all teachings. He is called Laozi, the embodiment of the Dao. His manifestations are not singular, and his titles are boundless—sometimes thirty-six, sometimes seventy-two. He may be called the Supreme August Emperor of the Nine Heavens, the Sovereign of the Cavern-Realm and Primordial Unity, the Most High Jade Emperor, the Great Emperor of Longevity, the Marvelous Black August Lord of Supreme Peace and Perfect Authenticity, the Emperor of the Nine Mysteries, the Dharma King of the Great Thousand, the Elder of the Nine Numinous, the Left Mystic Perfected of the Supreme Clarity, the Great Dharma Master of the Three Caverns’ Wondrous Scriptures of the Golden Palace, the Most High Great Dharma King, the Mystic Unity of True Stillness and Light, the Latter Sage of the Golden Palace, the Lord of the Nine Elders’ Immortal Capital, the Nine-Black Elder, the Supreme Elder, the Lord of the Twelve Hundred Offices, the Supreme Scenery Lord of Supreme Peace, the Father of Non-Action, or the Mother of the Myriad Things.

At the time of his descent into the world, the divine beings of the ten directions reverently bear wisdom, the Most Honored, the Teacher of Emperors, the Great Man, the Venerable Immortal, the Father of Heaven and Humankind, the Supreme Person of Non-Action, the Great Compassionate One, the Benevolent, and the Master of the True Origin. The heavenly and earthly beings praise him with ten titles: the Lord of Non-Action, the Supreme Mystic Elder, the Most Venerable Lord Lao, the Most High Laozi, the Great Emperor of the Heavenly Sovereign, the Great Dharma Master of the Mystic Center, the Ancient Great Master, the Emperor of the Golden Palace, the Most High Supreme August, and the Great Perfected of Emptiness and Non-Being. He is also known by titles such as the Perfect and Boundless Great Dao, the Natural and Primordial Most High Heavenly Worthy, the Lord of the Dao, the Supreme Heavenly Perfected, the Heavenly Elder, the Heavenly Master, the Yellow Elder, the Mystic Ancestor, the Teacher of the World, the Divine Person, the Perfected, the Immortal, the Utmost Person, the Great Person, the Daoist, and the Sage. The titles from the Heavenly Perfected downward each consist of two characters.

The Most Venerable Lord, the Cavern-Realm’s Ultimate Sage, has no fixed form. When he dissolves, he becomes darkness; when he rests, he becomes human. At times, he coalesces into his true form within the Great Void, his body boundless, his features perfectly complete, with nothing above to grasp and nothing below to tread upon. At other times, he resides upon the Cloud Blossom, his body golden, attended by ten thousand perfected beings and revered by a hundred spirits. Or he sits within a lotus, wearing a crown adorned with the Seven Luminaries, draped in a nine-colored radiant robe, his neck bearing a halo that illuminates heaven and earth. Or he dwells in a jeweled hall and golden palace, surrounded by pearl and jade curtains, as ten thousand emperors pay homage and divine soldiers guard his carriage. Sometimes his form is golden and jade-like, clad in yellow garments and embroidered robes; at others, he wears plain robes and a dark cap, riding a white horse with a red mane. At times, he governs the Ten Heavens, sealing and overseeing the myriad people, residing in the Supreme Subtlety, the Curved Array, or the Purple Chamber as the Great Emperor of the Heavenly Sovereign. In spring, he transforms into the Supreme Scenery Lord, nine thousand *zhang* tall, wearing a crown of the Seven Treasures’ radiant flowers, dressed in robes of dark yellow and black, with a flying skirt of blue brocade, holding a tiger tally, and seated upon a seven-colored cloud.
chunks.overlap_context: clipse. The heavenly principles complete one revolution in three hundred thirty days; the earthly mechanisms advance one degree in three thousand three hundred days. Nine thousand nine hundred degrees mark the convergence of heaven and earth’s qi, known as the Great Yang Nine and the Great Hundred Six—also called the Great Kalpa and the Great Cycle. Multiplying these numbers, a minor yang comet occurs roughly once every three hundred thirty years, which constitutes the Lesser Yang Nine Calamity.

chunks.original_text: 或夏化为老前，戴九龙之冠，衣黄纹之衣，服黄羽之裙，手执金板，立紫云之上。 或秋化为童子，衣五色之衣，或乘狮子，或坐青云。 或冬化为苍玄青三色之光，光明混沌更相缠绕，此则返金阙之黑，更受炼飞玄通晨之精也。 或化身为玄天大帝，经云八十二变为真武。 故佑圣真君启请有云：仰启玄天大圣者，北方壬癸至灵神，金阙真尊应化身，无上将军号真武也。 其神通自在，随感则现，能白能黑，能方能圆，能屈能伸，能修能短，能老能少，能一能万，纵横反覆，厥体靡常。 或为千二百老子，应现诸天。 或为百八十道君，接引凡世，分灵散景，倏忽周褊，而真一之身湛然常寂，常在太清太极宫也。 老君尝以上和元年岁在庚寅九月三日甲子，化生於郁单北玄玉国天呈灵镜山李谷之问，上玄灵母九玄之房。 初，母之始孕，梦玄云日月缠其形，六气之电动其神，遂有妊。 既诞之辰，有三日并出，乃以谷为氏族，用曜景为名。 一名弘，字子光，一名玄水，字山渊。 上和乃天上之纪年也，如赤明、朱灵、清汉、天汉、开皇、上皇之类也。 而世俗之士秪知甲子造於大挠，年号始於汉武，便以上和等号皆谓之妄，殊不知上天自亿劫以前，纪年不废，世人无从而知耳。 自鬼谷子、北郭子、张天师、葛仙公等方引诸天之号以配人间时代也，不然则诸仙博古该今，穷幽究微，岂不知秦汉之前未有年号耶。 至如开辟之初，建立法度，及世代因革，悉由上天数定，时遣天真降教以传人世耳，非世人能先天而肇造也，学者详之。 於是敛魂研魄，守胎宝神，录精镇血，固液凝筋，吞光饮霞，咀嚼飞根，内德圆充，外累远判，形分百万，变化无穷。 紫微上真天帝玉清君遣八景琼舆来迎，以登上清宫，授蕊刚丹玉凤玺，金真玉光，给神虎之符及飞行之羽，朱锦龙裙，青帔虎带，戴圆容神冠，受书为金阙后圣帝君。 老君於龙汉元年分身於中央大福堂国，出真文赤书以化其民，民皆长生。 又於南极赤明之国出火炼真文，故号洞阳之庭，有流火之池，人炼其形，皆成金色。 上置南昌之宫，下立朱陵之馆，以主生成。 老君以龙汉、赤明、上皇、延康、开皇五劫皆运始青、丹光、中灵、素华、玄阳之炁，轮转而为玉历、龙汉以来，渺渺亿劫，混沌之中寥廓无光，载籍叵考。 赤明开图，然后经典始可得而推也。 真文者，五方真炁之精凝结成文，八角垂芒，或为云篆之形，或成飞走之状，即今之符文，天真之信契也。 以上并互见於三洞真经也。 又於东极碧落之天，浮黎之国，书真文於空青之林，成紫字之文。 其林风声成音，鸟食其叶，身生文章。 人得其羽，即能飞行。 其民长生，安乐无为。 又於西极卫罗世界西那玉国，出真文於浮罗之岳，以度国人。 玉池自 生，金精流映，人挹其水，身生金光，与天相毕。 又於北方郁单之国，书真文於洞灵之观，以度兆民。 其下寒池灵津，自然流澳，人得饮之，无有终极。 此五土之内，皆禀老君灵宝之教，以得长生。 因命五老上帝，以镇五方。 行道垂教，和宁群品也。 《隋书经籍志》云：元始天尊生於太无之先，禀自然之炁，冲虚凝远，莫知其极，天地沦坏，劫数终尽，而天尊之体常存不灭。
chunks.translated_text:
In summer, he transforms into the Venerable Elder, wearing a crown of nine dragons, clad in robes of yellow patterns and a skirt of yellow feathers, holding a golden tablet, standing upon purple clouds. In autumn, he becomes a youth, dressed in five-colored garments, sometimes riding a lion, sometimes seated upon blue clouds. In winter, he manifests as a radiance of dark, mysterious, and azure hues, their luminous chaos intertwining—this is the return to the Black of the Golden Palace, where he further refines the essence of soaring mystery and dawn’s communion.

At times, he incarnates as the Great Emperor of the Dark Heavens. The scriptures say that in eighty-two transformations he becomes True Martial. Thus, the Invocation of the Protector Sage Perfected Lord declares: *"We reverently invoke the Great Sage of the Dark Heavens, the numinous spirit of the northern *ren* and *gui*, the True Honored One of the Golden Palace who manifests in response, the Supreme General known as True Martial."* His divine potency is self-sufficient; he appears as he is perceived. He can be white or black, square or round, bent or extended, long or short, old or young, one or ten thousand. His form shifts and reverses without constancy.

At times, he is the Twelve Hundred Elders, manifesting across the heavens. At others, he is the One Hundred Eighty Dao Lords, guiding the mortal world, dispersing his numinous radiance in fleeting, boundless presence—yet the essence of his True One remains serene and eternally quiescent, ever abiding in the Grand Clarity and the Palace of the Supreme Ultimate.

Once, in the first year of *Shanghe*—the year *gengyin* of the celestial reckoning, on the ninth day of the ninth month, the *jiazi* day—Lord Lao was born within the Jade Country of the Northern *Yudan* realm, at the Valley of Li between the Heavenly Mirror Mountain. His mother, the Mysterious Numinous Mother of the Nine Mysteries’ Chamber, first conceived him in a dream where dark clouds, sun, and moon entwined her form, and the lightning of the Six Qi stirred her spirit, thus quickening with child. On the day of his birth, three suns rose together, and so he took the valley as his clan name and the radiant light as his given name. He was also called *Hong*, styled *Ziguang*; another name was *Xuanshui*, styled *Shanyuan*.

*Shanghe* is but one of the celestial eras, akin to *Chiming*, *Zhuling*, *Qinghan*, *Tianhan*, *Kaihuang*, and *Shanghuang*. Yet worldly scholars, knowing only that the *jiazi* cycle was devised by *Danao* and that reign titles began with Emperor Wu of Han, dismiss such celestial eras as fabrications. Little do they realize that the heavens have recorded years since countless kalpas past, though mortals remain unaware.

From *Guiguzi* to *Beiguozi*, from Celestial Master Zhang to *Ge Xian’gong*, all have drawn upon celestial era names to align with mortal ages. Otherwise, how could these immortals, versed in ancient and modern lore, delving into the profound and subtle, be ignorant that reign titles did not exist before Qin and Han? From the dawn of creation, when laws and institutions were established, to the rise and fall of dynasties, all is predestined by heaven, which dispatches celestial perfected beings to transmit teachings to the mortal world—not by mortal hands could such be devised beforehand. Let scholars ponder this.

Thereupon, he gathered his hun souls and refined his po spirits, guarded the womb’s treasured spirit, recorded his essence and stabilized his blood, solidified his fluids and strengthened his sinews. He swallowed light and drank mist, chewed the roots of flight, his inner virtue perfectly full, his external burdens far severed. His forms multiplied into millions, his transformations boundless.

The Supreme Perfected Lord of the Purple Tenuity and the Jade Clarity Heavenly Emperor dispatched an eight-scene jade chariot to welcome him, ascending to the Palace of Supreme Clarity. There, he was bestowed the *Ruigang* Elixir and the Jade Phoenix Seal, the Golden Perfection and Jade Radiance, the talismans of the Divine Tiger and the feathers of flight, a crimson brocade dragon skirt, a blue mantle with tiger belt, and the Crown of Round Countenance. He received the scriptures and was named the Posterior Sage Emperor Lord of the Golden Palace.

In the first year of *Longhan*, Lord Lao divided his body in the Central Land of Great Blessing, revealing the True Writ of Red Script to transform its people, who all attained longevity. Later, in the Southern Culmen’s *Chiming* Land, he issued the Fire-Refined True Writ, thus naming it the Court of Cavernous Yang, where a Pool of Flowing Fire exists. Those who refined their forms therein became golden in hue. Above, he established the Palace of Southern Prosperity; below, the Lodge of Vermilion Mound, to govern generation and completion.

Across the five kalpas of *Longhan*, *Chiming*, *Shanghuang*, *Yankang*, and *Kaihuang*, Lord Lao cyclically wielded the qi of *Beginning Green*, *Cinnabar Radiance*, *Central Numinosity*, *Pristine Florescence*, and *Mysterious Yang*, revolving them into the Jade Calendar. Since *Longhan*, through boundless kalpas, within the vastness of primordial chaos where no light shone, records could not be traced. Only with the *Chiming* Unfolding Chart did scriptures become discernible.

The True Writ is the essence of the Five Directions’ true qi, congealed into script, its eight corners trailing rays. It may take the form of cloud-seal characters or assume the shapes of flight and movement—these are the talismanic writs of today, the covenants of celestial perfected beings. The above is found interspersed within the Three Caverns’ true scriptures.

Moreover, in the Eastern Culmen’s *Biluo* Heaven, within the *Fuli* Land, he inscribed the True Writ upon the Azure Forest, forming characters of purple hue. The wind through its trees produced music, and birds that ate its leaves grew patterned plumage. Those who obtained its feathers could fly. Its people lived long, at peace and without striving.

In the Western Culmen’s *Weiluo* World, within the *Xinayu* Land, he issued the True Writ upon the *Fuluo* Peaks to deliver its people. Jade pools arose spontaneously, golden essence flowed and shimmered; those who ladled its waters grew golden radiance, becoming equal to heaven.

In the Northern Land of *Yudan*, he inscribed the True Writ within the Cavernous Numinosity Abbey to deliver its multitudes. Below lay the Cold Pool’s numinous springs, naturally flowing and abundant; those who drank thereof knew no end.

Within these five lands, all received Lord Lao’s teachings of the Numinous Treasure, attaining longevity. Thus, he commanded the Five Elder Thearchs to guard the Five Directions, propagating the Dao and extending teachings to harmonize and pacify all beings.

The *History of the Sui Dynasty: Treatise on Classics and Books* states: *"The Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning was born before the Great Nonbeing, inheriting the qi of spontaneity. Profound and distant, none know his limits. Though heaven and earth collapse and kalpas end, the body of the Celestial Worthy remains eternally indestructible."*
