chunks.original_text: 其要曰：夫人之生也，天付之以神，地付之以精，中和付之以。 人能保精爱神护黑，内则致身长，外则致国太平。 又曰：人臣之行，当上爱其君。 欲以长生，为人子者当念父母，畏其将老，风化其意，使之入道，常为求索奇方殊术以奉君亲。 为人弟子者当念绿师恩，夫人生於父母，成道德於师，得尊荣於君，每念君父师将老，无以复之，或行学更事贤明，求奇方异法而资益之。 此乃应太古上皇最善忠臣孝子顺弟子也，人皆为之，则天下太平矣。 有心之人所作皆善，言行精实，心自克责，洒心易行，感动於上，受天施恩，辄言报谢，精专不息，得致神仙。 其方曰：吾字十一名为士，丙午丁未为祖始，四口治事万物理，子巾用角治其右，潜龙勿用坎为巳，人得见之寿长久。 居天地问活而已，治万百人仙可待，善理病者勿期给，乐莫乐乎长安市，使人寿若西王母，比若四时周反始，九十字策传方士。 盖神丹奇策可以奉君父师者焉。 又出科戒祭酒之法以付吉，吉后奉经行道，分布弟子，置男官、女官，广化人民，四方归向。 后汉章帝元和二年，老君复降，请责吉曰：吾前授汝道，助国扶命，忧念万兆，而顷以来，诸男女弟子托吾位号，贪财纵欲，骄倨自大，嫉贤拓才，更相是非，皆不当尔，故来语汝。 吉稽首伏地，叩头百下曰：唯唯，愿太上赦既往之罪，容臣修将来之善，从今日已往，不知当何以救诸男女弟子之谴谪。 老君曰：汝善听，汝善听，人生虽寿万年，不持戒律，与老木久石何异，宁一日持戒为道德之人而死，不忍犯戒而生。 持戒者上补天官，尸解升仙。 世人虽为王公，上至帝皇，脱有重罪，无益魂神，可不#3痛耶。 明奉吾戒以教授之。 乃为说一百八十戒。 讫，又语吉曰：往古仙圣皆从此得道，道本无形，从师得成，道不可废，师不可轻。 吉稽首受命，再拜而谢。 按《后汉裴楷传》云：楷，孝桓帝时复上书言：前者宫崇所献神书，专以奉天地，)lM五行为本，亦有兴国广嗣之衍，其文易晓，参同经典。 而顺帝不行，故国嗣不兴。 楷言多切直，帝不能用。 章怀太子注引《太平经》兴帝王篇曰：真人问神人曰：吾欲使帝王立致太平，其可闻耶。 神人言：但顺天地之道，不失殊分，则立致太平。 元熙有三名，为太阳、太阴、中和。 形体有三名，为天、地、人。 天有三名，为日、月、星，北极为中也。 地有三名，为山、川与平土。 人有三名，为父、母、子。 政有三名，为君、臣、民。 此三者，常相得腹心，不失铢分，使其同忧，合成一家，立致太平，延年不疑也。 灵帝即位，以楷言为然。 太傅陈蕃举楷方正，不就。 乡里宗之，每太守至，辄政礼。 清平中，与苟爽、郑元或作玄字俱以博士召，不至。

The essentials state: *"When a person is born, Heaven bestows upon them spirit, Earth bestows upon them essence, and the harmonious center bestows upon them [qi]. If one can preserve essence, cherish spirit, and guard the Mysterious, within they will attain longevity, and without they will bring the realm to Great Peace."*

It further states: *"A minister’s conduct should be to love their ruler above all. Those who desire long life—if they are children—should think of their parents, fearing their aging, and guide their intentions toward the Dao, constantly seeking rare formulas and extraordinary arts to serve their lord and kin. As disciples, they should remember their masters’ grace, for though one is born of parents, it is through masters that virtue and power are perfected, and through rulers that honor and glory are attained. Ever mindful that their lord, father, and master will age, and having no means to repay them, they should study further and serve the worthy, seeking rare formulas and wondrous methods to benefit them. Such are the most loyal ministers, filial children, and obedient disciples of the Highest Antiquity and August Sovereign. If all people act thus, the world will attain Great Peace."*

*"Those with heart do only good, their words and deeds sincere and substantial. They examine themselves strictly, purify their hearts, and reform their conduct. Moved by this, those above bestow Heaven’s grace, and they, in turn, express gratitude and remain steadfast without ceasing, thereby attaining immortality."*

The formula states: *"My character ‘eleven’ is named ‘Scholar.’ *Bing-wu* and *ding-wei* are the ancestral beginnings. Four mouths govern affairs and the principles of all things. The ‘Child’s Turban’ uses the horn to govern the right. The ‘Hidden Dragon’ must not be employed—*kan* corresponds to *si*. Those who behold it live long. Dwelling between Heaven and Earth, one merely lives, but governing a hundred thousand people, immortality awaits. Those who skillfully cure illness need not seek recompense. There is no joy like the Long Peace Market, making people’s lives as long as the Queen Mother of the West, akin to the four seasons cycling endlessly. Ninety characters and strategies are transmitted to the fangshi. These divine elixirs and marvelous strategies may be offered to one’s lord, father, and master."*

Furthermore, [the scripture] expounded the regulations and precepts for *jijiu* (libationers) and entrusted them to Gan Ji. Thereafter, Ji revered the scriptures, practiced the Dao, and disseminated them among his disciples, establishing male and female officials to broadly transform the people, drawing followers from all directions.

In the second year of *Yuanhe* during the reign of Emperor Zhang of the Later Han, the Lord Lao descended again and admonished Ji, saying: *"I previously transmitted the Dao to you to assist the state and sustain life, worrying for the myriad people. Yet of late, male and female disciples have usurped my titles, coveting wealth, indulging desires, acting arrogantly, envying the worthy, and obstructing talent, engaging in mutual slander—none of this is as it should be. Thus, I have come to speak with you."*

Ji prostrated himself, touching his head to the ground a hundred times, and said: *"Yes, yes! May the Most High pardon past transgressions and permit this servant to cultivate future goodness. From this day forward, I know not how to save the male and female disciples from their misfortunes."*

The Lord Lao said: *"Listen well, listen well! Though a person may live ten thousand years, without upholding the precepts, what difference is there from ancient wood or enduring stone? Better to die as a person of virtue and power for a single day while upholding the precepts than to live in violation of them. Those who uphold the precepts supplement the celestial offices and ascend as *shi jie* immortals. Though worldly people may be kings, dukes, or even emperors, if they commit grave sins, it avails nothing for their souls and spirits. How can this not be grievous? Clearly uphold my precepts to instruct them."*

Thereupon, he expounded one hundred and eighty precepts. Having finished, he further told Ji: *"The immortals and sages of ancient times all attained the Dao through this. The Dao is originally formless; it is perfected through the master. The Dao must not be abandoned, nor the master slighted."*

Ji bowed deeply, received the command, and expressed his gratitude with repeated bows.

According to the *Biography of Pei Kai* in the *History of the Later Han*: Kai, during the reign of Emperor Huan, again memorialized, saying: *"Formerly, Gong Chong presented divine books that focused on revering Heaven and Earth, taking the Five Phases as their foundation. They also contained methods for strengthening the state and increasing descendants, their texts being easily understood and aligning with the classics. Yet Emperor Shun did not implement them, and thus the imperial line did not flourish."* Kai’s words were often forthright and direct, but the emperor did not adopt them.

The *Commentary of Crown Prince Zhanghuai* cites the *"Rise of Emperors and Kings"* chapter of the *Scripture of Great Peace*, which states: *"A perfected person asked a divine person: ‘I wish to enable emperors and kings to swiftly attain Great Peace. May I hear how?’ The divine person replied: ‘Simply follow the Way of Heaven and Earth without losing their distinct divisions, and Great Peace will be swiftly attained.’*

*‘*Yuanxi’ has three names: Great Yang, Great Yin, and the Harmonious Center. Forms have three names: Heaven, Earth, and Human. Heaven has three names: sun, moon, and stars, with the North Pole as the center. Earth has three names: mountains, rivers, and level land. Humans have three names: father, mother, and child. Governance has three names: ruler, minister, and people. If these three constantly support one another as if of one mind, not losing even the slightest measure, sharing the same concerns and uniting as one family, Great Peace will be swiftly attained, and longevity will be unquestionable."*

When Emperor Ling ascended the throne, he deemed Kai’s words correct. The Grand Mentor Chen Fan recommended Kai as *fangzheng* (upright and principled), but he did not accept the appointment. His hometown revered him, and whenever a new governor arrived, he would be the first to pay respects.

During the *Qingping* era, he was summoned along with Xun Shuang and Zheng Xuan (or Zheng Yuan) as *boshi* (erudites), but he did not go.

chunks.original_text: 范晔论曰：古人有云，善言天者铃有验於人。 而张衡亦云：天文历数、阴阳占候，今所宜急也，郎颤、裴楷能仰瞻俯察，参诸人事，祸福吉凶既应，引之教义亦明。 此盖道衍所以有补於时，后人所当取镒者也。 吉后寓居会稽。 孙策平江束，见士民事吉如神，遂招为客，留军中。 将士多疾疫，请吉噗水辄差。 将士咸崇仰吉，日一先拜吉而后朝策。 策怒，乃收吉，责数曰：天久旱，水道不能，君安坐船中，作鬼态，束吾将士，败吾部曲，今当相除。 即缚吉，暴使请雨，若能感天今日日中大雨者，当相原，不者加诛。 俄而云兴，雨大注。 策竟杀吉，将士涕泣，欲收葬，俄失其尸。 策寻为许贡伏客所伤，览镜见吉在镜中。 策大惊，掷镜大呼，创裂而死。 吉尚周旋人问百余年，然后仙去。 已上元未注所出，此略见《太平经序》、《太平经》本文。 安帝永初三年己酉二月，老君降于泰山，遣泰山使者雅羽以车骑召江夏善士刘图，欲使校定天下簿籍。 图至，见老君当殿，南面而坐。 太上居束，西向，九天仙君居南，北向，八极天君居西，束向，命图与官属校定天下名求重应籍，三日而毕。 老君欲示图以罪福报，乃令羽将图入地狱，凡至八十一，图见父在狱受苦，出告老君为父哀，乃命释之。 又令将图至天堂，见大清宫中金台玉殿，音乐自然，仙真多着青衣，执金简，歌诵经文。 观毕遣回，图因此得道，遂为道士，后亦仙去。 见《唐史纪圣赋》及《应元图》。 顺帝汉安元年壬午正月十五日，老君乘云车，群仙侍卫，降于蜀之临叩鹤呜山张陵修炼之所，敕神人呼陵至前，谓曰：子祖张良积功致德，垂福后嗣，子命应为道士。 即授以新出《正一盟威秘录》，俾除荡六天故黑，以清化天下。 及朝拜日月高奔郁仪结璘之诀，令修习之。 自是百姓翕然，奉之为师，弟子至数万。 民有疾患官灾，随事输米、绢、丝、绵、杂器、纸、笔、樵薪之属以赎罪，并疏其过恶而忏谢之，誓不敢复犯，灾难随解。 由是民皆乐从，莫敢为非。

Fan Ye’s commentary states: The ancients said, "He who speaks well of Heaven must have verification in man." Zhang Heng likewise declared: "Astronomy, calendrical calculations, yin-yang divination, and prognostications—these are what we must urgently attend to today." Only men like Lang Yi and Pei Kai could look up to observe the heavens and look down to examine the earth, correlating them with human affairs. When fortune and misfortune, good and ill omens duly manifested, they drew upon them to clarify moral teachings. This is how the unfolding of the Dao/Way proved beneficial to the age, and what later generations should take as their measure.

Ji Hou later took up residence in Kuaiji. When Sun Ce pacified the Jiangdong region, seeing that the people revered Ji as a divine being, he invited him to be a guest and kept him in his army. Many officers and soldiers fell ill with epidemics, but whenever Ji spat water upon them, they would recover. The officers and soldiers all venerated Ji, bowing to him each day before paying their respects to Sun Ce. Enraged, Sun Ce arrested Ji and reproached him, saying: "Heaven has long been parched, and the waterways are dry. Yet you sit idly in your boat, playing the sorcerer, bewitching my officers and soldiers and disrupting my ranks. Today I shall do away with you." He bound Ji and exposed him, demanding that he summon rain. "If you can move Heaven to send a great downpour by midday, I shall pardon you. If not, you will be executed." Soon clouds gathered, and rain poured down in torrents. Sun Ce nevertheless put Ji to death. His officers and soldiers wept, wishing to recover his body for burial, but suddenly his corpse vanished. Soon after, Sun Ce was wounded by assassins sent by Xu Gong. Gazing into a mirror, he saw Ji’s reflection. Sun Ce cried out in terror, hurled the mirror away, and died as his wound burst open. Ji continued to move among people for over a hundred years before ascending as an immortal.

The above account is not sourced in the *Yuan* registers; it is briefly recorded in the *Preface to the Scripture of Great Peace* and the main text of the *Scripture of Great Peace*.

In the third year of the *Yongchu* era of Emperor An, on the *jiyou* day of the second month (Year of the Rooster), the Venerable Lord descended upon Mount Tai. He dispatched the Mount Tai emissary Ya Yu with chariots and cavalry to summon Liu Tu, a virtuous scholar of Jiangxia, intending to have him collate and verify the registers of all under Heaven. When Tu arrived, he saw the Venerable Lord seated facing south upon the throne. The Most High resided in the east, facing west; the Nine Heavens’ Immortal Lords resided in the south, facing north; and the Eight Poles’ Heavenly Lords resided in the west, facing east. The Venerable Lord commanded Tu and his officials to collate and verify the names and karmic registers of all under Heaven, completing the task in three days. Wishing to show Tu the retribution of sins and blessings, the Venerable Lord ordered Ya Yu to lead Tu into the earthly prisons. They passed through eighty-one hells, where Tu saw his father suffering in torment. Upon emerging, he pleaded with the Venerable Lord on his father’s behalf, and the Venerable Lord commanded his release. Ya Yu then led Tu to the heavenly realms, where he beheld the Golden Terrace and Jade Palace within the Great Clarity Palace. Music arose spontaneously, and many immortals, clad in azure robes and holding golden tablets, chanted and recited scriptures. After the tour, Tu was sent back. Through this experience, he attained the Dao/Way, became a Daoist priest, and later ascended as an immortal.

This account appears in the *Rhapsody on the Sage’s Chronicle in the Tang History* and the *Yingyuan Diagram*.

In the first year of the *Han’an* era of Emperor Shun, on the fifteenth day of the first month (Year of the Horse), the Venerable Lord descended upon Mount Heming in Shu, where Zhang Ling was cultivating the Dao/Way. Riding a cloud chariot and attended by a host of immortals, he summoned Zhang Ling before him through divine messengers and said: "Your ancestor Zhang Liang accumulated merit and virtue, bestowing blessings upon his descendants. Your destiny is to become a Daoist priest." He then bestowed upon Zhang the newly revealed *Secret Registers of the Orthodox Unity Alliance of Might*, instructing him to sweep away the residual darkness of the Six Heavens and purify the world through transformation. He also taught him the methods of paying homage to the sun and moon, and the techniques of the *High Ascent* and *Yuyi* and *Jielin* rituals, commanding him to practice them. From then on, the people flocked to him as their teacher, and his disciples numbered in the tens of thousands. When the people suffered from illnesses or official calamities, they would offer rice, silk, cloth, hemp, miscellaneous utensils, paper, brushes, firewood, and the like to atone for their sins. They would also submit written confessions of their transgressions, repent, and swear never to repeat them, whereupon their misfortunes would dissolve. Thus, the people all delighted in following him, and none dared to do wrong.

chunks.original_text: 初，陵后名道陵，字辅汉以光武建武十年甲午正月十五日生於余杭之天目山，七岁能诵《道德经》。 后为书生，博综五经，通河洛象纬之文。 章帝元和二年乙酉，以博士召，不起。 时年五十二，自谓儒学无益於年命，乃叹曰：人生几何，老死将及，不能复经生死之苦。 遂散其门人，行学长生之道，隐居于云锦山。 今信州龙虎山是也。 和帝永元四年壬辰，就拜谏议大夫，辞疾不拜。 帝复以三品印绶驷马车征为太傅，封冀县侯。 陵语使者曰：为我谢天子，九霄之上、无何有之乡金阙帝君，某已为之臣矣。 惟清静寡欲，天下自治，何以陵为。 遂转入嵩山，斋戒念道，常诵《道德经》。 积九年，精感老君遣神人告云：中岳石室中有上古三皇天文、《黄帝九鼎大丹经》、《五岳真形图》，子可往受之。 乃入石室中，果得天文宝经、黄帝九鼎丹法。 而陵家素贫，无赀可炼，闻蜀人朴厚可教化，且多名山，乃将弟子入蜀，於鹤呜山隐居。 既遇老君，遂於隐居之所备药物，依法修炼。 三年丹成，未敢服饵，谓弟子曰：神丹已成，若服之，当冲天为真人。 然未有大功於世，须为国家除害兴利，以济民庶，然后服丹轻举，臣事三境，庶无魄焉。 老君寻遣清和玉女教以吐纳清和之法，修行千日，能内见五藏，外集万神。 乃三步九迹，交乾履斗，随呈所指以摄精邪，战六天魔鬼，夺二十四治，改为福庭，名之化宇，降其师为阴官。 先时，蜀中魔鬼数万，白昼为市，擅行疫疠，生民久罹其害。 自六天大魔摧伏之后，陵斥其鬼众散处西北不毛之地，与之为誓曰：人主於昼，鬼行於夜，阴阳分别，各有司存，违者正一有法，必加诛戮。 於是幽明异域，人鬼殊途。 今西蜀青城有鬼市，并天师誓鬼碑石、天地石日月存焉。 其誓盖指此为约，谓天地合日月明乃许汝出也。 五月一日，老君再降，授陵以《太清中篇经目》九卷、《金液丹经》三十六卷、《太清中经》、《室中秘要》二十四卷、《玄女秘妙经》、《素真经》、《始阴经》、《九鼎变化炼真玄洞之法开明大经》、《玉策山纪图录》、《山海大戒河洛图谶》、内外《黄庭》、内外《太清》、《玉策幽经》、《五行精微东井沐浴经》、《天镜》、《地镜》、《明镜》、《山镜》等经，《变景经》、《合景内视经》、《九天元谱》、《九天元洞九真中经》、《五老宝经》、《丹简黑录》、《上下斋品戒文》、《太一金液经》、《真一守玄经》、《三元中胎素灵中经》、《金阙帝君青童内经》、《洞玄真经》、《三皇内文》、《宣化思道成败观戒》、《三五飞步呈玄经》、《甲山图》、《明禁地录》、《鬼历诸法》，凡九百三十卷，符文七十卷，合一千卷。 老君复命陵縿侍龙驾，至昆仑板风金慵七宝台。 时玉晨大道君游处其问，老君将陵朝礼玉晨，於是救青童付陵天师印绶，使按千二百官，仍赐雌雄二剑、二仪交泰冠、驱邪岐、鱼鬣服、符录契令、经戒法律，使助国扶命，养生制恶。 陵拜毕复还。 建康元年甲申，天师徙居闱州云台山。 十月十五日，老君再降，授以《正一盟威经》、三业六通之诀及三洞众经、岁月二斋法，皆披《灵宝五篇》自然天书大字为旨要妙经。

At the outset, his successor was named **Dao-ling**, styled **Fu-Han**, born in the fifteenth day of the first lunar month of the *jiawu* year (10 CE) during the reign of Emperor Guangwu’s *Jianwu* era, in the Tianmu Mountains of Yuhang. At the age of seven, he could recite the *Dao De Jing*. Later, he became a scholar, mastering the Five Classics and well-versed in the writings of the *He* and *Luo* Rivers, as well as celestial patterns. In the second year of Emperor Zhang’s *Yuanhe* era (*yiyou*, 85 CE), he was summoned as a *boshi* (erudite) but declined the appointment. At fifty-two, he declared that Confucian learning was of no benefit to longevity and lamented: *"How fleeting is human life! Old age and death draw near, and I cannot endure the suffering of life and death again."* He then dispersed his disciples and pursued the Dao of long life, retreating to Yunjin Mountain—now known as Longhu Mountain in Xinzhou.

In the fourth year of Emperor He’s *Yongyuan* era (*renchen*, 92 CE), he was appointed *Jianyidafu* (Remonstrating Grand Master) but declined due to illness. The emperor again summoned him with a third-rank seal and cord, a four-horse carriage, and the title of *Taifu* (Grand Tutor), enfeoffing him as Marquis of Jixian. Dao-ling told the envoy: *"Convey my gratitude to the Son of Heaven: in the Nine Heavens above, in the realm of Nothingness, the Golden-Portal Lord of the Imperial Palace—I have already become his subject. Only through purity and restraint can the world govern itself. What need has it of me?"* He then withdrew to Mount Song, where he fasted, meditated on the Dao, and constantly recited the *Dao De Jing*. After nine years of cultivation, his sincerity moved Lord Lao, who dispatched a divine messenger to inform him: *"Within the stone chamber of the Central Peak lie the ancient celestial texts of the Three Sovereigns, the* Huangdi Jiuding Great Elixir Scripture*, and the* Five Marchmounts True Forms Map*. You may go and receive them."* Entering the stone chamber, he indeed obtained the celestial treasures and the *Huangdi Jiuding* elixir methods. However, his family had long been poor, lacking the means to refine the elixir. Hearing that the people of Shu were simple and teachable, and that the region abounded in famous mountains, he led his disciples into Shu and secluded himself on Mount Heming.

There, he encountered Lord Lao, who provided the necessary ingredients. Following the method, he refined the elixir for three years. Upon its completion, he dared not consume it, telling his disciples: *"The divine elixir is now ready. If I take it, I shall ascend to become a Perfected. Yet I have not rendered great service to the world. I must first eliminate harm and promote benefit for the state, aiding the people, before I consume the elixir, ascend lightly, and serve the Three Realms—lest I feel remorse."* Soon after, Lord Lao sent the Pure Harmony Jade Maiden to teach him the method of exhaling and inhaling pure harmony. After a thousand days of practice, he could inwardly perceive his five viscera and outwardly gather the myriad spirits. He then took three steps and nine strides, treading the Dipper and the Qian trigram, wielding his power to subdue demonic forces wherever they manifested. He battled the demonic lords of the Six Heavens, seized the Twenty-Four *Zhi*, transformed them into blessed precincts, and renamed them *Huayu* (Realms of Transformation), demoting their former masters to the rank of *yin* officials.

Previously, tens of thousands of demonic spirits in Shu had roamed freely, holding markets in broad daylight, spreading plagues, and afflicting the people for generations. After the great demons of the Six Heavens were subdued, Dao-ling banished their hordes to the barren lands of the northwest. He swore an oath with them: *"Humans rule by day, ghosts by night. Yin and yang are distinct, each with its own domain. Those who violate this shall face the laws of the* Zhengyi*, and be punished without mercy."* Thus, the realms of the living and the dead were separated, and their paths diverged. To this day, the "Ghost Market" at Qingcheng in western Shu, along with the stele of Dao-ling’s oath to the spirits and the celestial and terrestrial stones bearing the sun and moon, remain. The oath stipulated that the spirits could only emerge when heaven and earth aligned and the sun and moon shone brightly.

On the first day of the fifth month, Lord Lao descended again, bestowing upon Dao-ling the following scriptures: nine scrolls of the *Taiqing Zhongpian Jingmu*, thirty-six scrolls of the *Jinye Danjing*, twenty-four scrolls of the *Taiqing Zhongjing* and *Shizhong Miyao*, the *Xuannü Mimiao Jing*, *Suzhen Jing*, *Shiyin Jing*, *Jiuding Bianhua Lianzhen Xuandong Zhi Fa Kaiming Dajing*, *Yuce Shanji Tulu*, *Shanhai Dajie Heluo Tuchen*, the inner and outer *Huangting*, the inner and outer *Taiqing*, *Yuce Youjing*, *Wuxing Jingwei Dongjing Muyu Jing*, *Tianjing*, *Dijing*, *Mingjing*, *Shanjing*, the *Bianjing Jing*, *Hejing Neishi Jing*, *Jiutian Yuanpu*, *Jiutian Yuan Dongjiu Zhen Zhongjing*, *Wulao Baojing*, *Danjian Heilu*, *Shangxia Zhaipin Jiewen*, *Taiyi Jinye Jing*, *Zhenyi Shouxuan Jing*, *Sanyuan Zhongtai Suling Zhongjing*, *Jinque Dijun Qingtong Neijing*, *Dongxuan Zhenjing*, *Sanhuang Neiwen*, *Xuanhua Sidao Chengbai Guan Jie*, *Sanwu Feibu Chengxuan Jing*, *Jiashan Tu*, *Mingjin Dilu*, and the *Gui Li Zhufa*—totaling nine hundred and thirty scrolls—as well as seventy scrolls of talismans, making one thousand scrolls in all.

Lord Lao further commanded Dao-ling to attend his dragon-drawn chariot to the Seven-Treasure Terrace of Kunlun’s Banfeng and Jincong. There, the Jade Dawn Great Dao Lord was in residence. Lord Lao presented Dao-ling to pay homage, whereupon the Jade Lad was dispatched to bestow upon Dao-ling the seal and cord of the Celestial Master, entrusting him with the governance of the twelve hundred officials. He also granted him the male and female swords, the *Eryi Jiaotai* crown, the *Quxie Qi*, the *Yulie* robe, talismans, registers, contracts, and commandments, along with scriptures and precepts, charging him to assist the state, protect destiny, nurture life, and suppress evil.

After the rites, Dao-ling returned. In the first year of *Jiankang* (*jiashen*, 144 CE), the Celestial Master moved to Mount Yuntai in Guizhou. On the fifteenth day of the tenth month, Lord Lao descended once more, bestowing upon him the *Zhengyi Mengwei Jing*, the secrets of the Three Actions and Six Penetrations, the scriptures of the Three Caverns, and the methods of the two seasonal fasts, all revealed through the celestial characters of the *Lingbao Wupian* as the essential and wondrous scriptures.

chunks.original_text: 今宣教十方天人，并甲子、庚申、八节、三元、五腊、三会，皆当沐浴斋戒，设献礼念，析谢愆犯、落灭黑簿、超度九祖斋值之法。 已上见《天师传》及《蜀图经》。 桓帝建和二年戊子正月七日，天师纳赵升为弟子。 又降十二神女，化咸泉为盐井。 后因名郡为陵，以旌其功。 后改为仙井盐，今为隆州也。 永寿元年乙未岁正月七日，老君再降，命陵同游成都。 老君驾龙车，陵乘白鹤，顿下五云，至太昊玉女修丹之所，地祇涌出，同捧一玉局，高可丈余，以为宝座。 为说北斗削死注生之法。 至十五日，又说南斗陶魂铸魄之功。 《南北二斗经》乃二侍真人叔迷其事而为经也。 老君既去，玉局尚存，地陷为井，今在成都子城内，号玉局观。 后又至鹿堂山，授陵以制六天斩邪之文。 永寿三年丙申，陵一百二十三岁也。 九月九日日中，老君遣五帝使者持玉策，降云台山，授陵正一真人号。 继有五色云龙来迎，遂与弟子王长、赵升同升天。 见《南北二斗经序》。 延熹八年乙巳八月甲子，帝梦老君乘华盖宝车降于殿庭，乃遣使诣陈国苦县致祠礼焉。 敕陈相边韶．撰碑文，其词云：老君为周守藏室史，当幽王时，三川实震，以夏、殷之季阴阳之事监喻时主。 孔子以周灵王二十一年生，问礼於老聪。 计其年纪，聘时已一百余岁。 孔子卒后百二十九年，谓周太史檐为老子，莫知其所终。 其二篇之书，称天地所以能长且久者，以不自生也。 厥初生民，遗体相续，其死生之义可知也。 或有谷神不死，是谓玄牝之言，由是世之好道者触类而长之，以老子离合於混沌之气，与三光为终始，观天作谶，升降斗星，随日九变，与时消息，规矩三光，四灵在旁，存想丹田，太一紫房，道成仙化，蝉蜕度世，自羲黄以来，世为圣者作师。 班固以老子绝圣弃智，礼为乱首，与仲尼，道违，述《汉书古今人表》，检以法度，抑、而下之，与楚子西同科。 二者论之殊矣，所谓道不同不相为谋也。 延熹八年八月甲子，皇上尊德弘道，含弘光大，存神养性，意在凌云，是以港心黄轩，同符高宗，梦见老子而尊祀之。 于时陈相边韶典国之礼，材．薄思浅，不能测度至人，辩是与非，按据书籍，以为老子玄虚守静，乐无名，守不德，危高官，安下位，遗孔子以仁言，辟世而隐居，变易名姓，唯恐见知。 夫日以幽明为节，月以亏盈自成，损益盛衰之原，倚伏祸福之门，天道恶盈而好谦。 盖老子所以见隆崇于今，为时人所享祀，乃其逃禄处微，损之又损之，显虚无之清寂，先天地生，乃守真养性，获五福之所致也。 敬演而铭之，其辞曰：於惟玄德，抱虚守清。 乐居下位，执禄不营。 为绳能直，屈之可萦。 三川之对，舒愤散呈。 见机而作，需郊出炯。 肥遁之吉，辟世隐声。 守一不失，为天下平。 处厚不薄，居实含荣。 楷式为重，金玉是轻。 绝嗜去欲，还归於婴。 浩然历载，莫知其情。 要以无为，大化用成。 进退无恒，错综其贞。 以知为愚，冲而不盈。 ·大人之度，非凡所评。 九等之叔，何足累名。 同光日月，合之五星。 出入丹庐，上下黄庭。 背弃流俗，舍景匿形。 包元神化，呼吸至精。 世不能原，知其死生。 天人秩祭，以昭厥灵。 羡彼延期，勒石是旌。

Now proclaiming the teachings to the ten directions’ celestial and human beings: on all *jiazi* days, *gengshen* days, the eight seasonal nodes, the Three Primes, the Five La Festivals, and the Three Assemblies, all must bathe, fast, and maintain abstinence, offering sacrifices, reciting invocations, and praying to atone for transgressions, erase entries from the Black Registers, and perform the rites of the Nine Ancestors’ Merit Feast. The above is recorded in the *Biography of the Celestial Master* and the *Illustrated Records of Shu*.

In the second year of *Jianhe* (*wuzǐ*, 148 CE), on the seventh day of the first month, the Celestial Master took Zhao Sheng as his disciple. Twelve divine maidens descended, transforming a bitter spring into a salt well. Later, the commandery was named *Ling* to commemorate his merit, and it was later renamed *Xianjing* Salt Well, now known as Longzhou.

In the first year of *Yongshou* (*yǐwèi*, 155 CE), on the seventh day of the first month, Lord Lao descended again, commanding the Celestial Master to travel together to Chengdu. Lord Lao rode a dragon chariot, while the Celestial Master mounted a white crane, alighting amidst five-colored clouds at the site where the Jade Maiden of Taihao refined the elixir. Earth spirits surged forth, jointly bearing a jade platform over ten feet high to serve as a sacred seat. There, Lord Lao expounded the methods of the Northern Dipper for excising death and inscribing life. By the fifteenth day, he further revealed the Southern Dipper’s powers of refining the hun-soul and forging the po-soul. The *Scriptures of the Northern and Southern Dippers* were later composed by the two attendant perfected ones, Shu and Mi, based on these events.

After Lord Lao departed, the jade platform remained, sinking into the earth to form a well, now located within the inner city of Chengdu, called the Jade Platform Abbey. Later, they traveled to Lutang Mountain, where Lord Lao bestowed upon the Celestial Master the *Texts for Subduing the Six Heavens and Beheading Demons*.

In the third year of *Yongshou* (*bǐngshēn*, 157 CE), the Celestial Master was one hundred and twenty-three years old. On the ninth day of the ninth month at noon, Lord Lao dispatched envoys of the Five Emperors bearing jade tablets, descending upon Mount Yuntai to confer upon him the title of *Zhengyi* Perfected One. Soon after, five-colored cloud-dragons arrived to welcome him, and together with his disciples Wang Chang and Zhao Sheng, he ascended to heaven. This is recorded in the preface to the *Scriptures of the Northern and Southern Dippers*.

In the eighth year of *Yanxi* (*yǐsì*, 165 CE), on the *jiazi* day of the eighth month, the Emperor dreamed of Lord Lao descending in a jeweled canopy chariot to the palace courtyard. He then dispatched envoys to offer sacrifices at his birthplace in Ku County of Chen Commandery. The Emperor ordered Bian Shao, the Chancellor of Chen, to compose an inscription, which read:

Lord Lao served as the Keeper of Archives for Zhou, and during the reign of King You, when the Three Rivers trembled, he admonished the ruler with the lessons of Xia and Yin’s decline, using the principles of yin and yang. Confucius, born in the twenty-first year of King Ling of Zhou, studied ritual with Lao Dan. Calculating his age, Lao Dan was already over a hundred when Confucius sought his instruction. One hundred and twenty-nine years after Confucius’ death, the Grand Scribe Tan of Zhou was identified as Laozi, though none knew his ultimate fate. His two-chapter work declares that the reason heaven and earth endure is that they do not live for themselves. From the dawn of humanity, bodies have succeeded one another, and the meaning of life and death is thus evident. Some speak of the "valley spirit that does not die," referring to the mysterious female, and from this, later seekers of the Dao expanded upon it, asserting that Laozi’s separation and union with the primordial qi marked the beginning and end of the Three Luminaries. Observing the heavens, he crafted prophecies, ascending and descending with the Dipper stars, changing nine times with the sun, waxing and waning with the seasons, measuring the Three Luminaries, with the Four Spirits at his side. By visualizing the cinnabar field and the Purple Chamber of the Great One, the Dao is perfected, immortality achieved, and one sheds the mortal coil to transcend the world. Since the eras of Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor, he has served as the teacher of sages.

Ban Gu, however, claimed that Laozi "abandoned sagacity and rejected knowledge," calling ritual the root of chaos, and thus diverged from Confucius. In his *Han History’s Table of Ancient and Modern Persons*, he applied standards to rank Laozi below Confucius, grouping him with Zixi of Chu. These two assessments differ greatly—such is the saying: "Those whose ways differ cannot make plans together."

In the eighth year of *Yanxi*, on the *jiazi* day of the eighth month, the Emperor, revering virtue and magnifying the Dao, embracing vastness and brilliance, cultivating spirit and nurturing nature, with aspirations to soar among the clouds, turned his heart toward the Yellow Emperor and emulated the example of Gaozong, dreaming of Laozi and honoring him with sacrifices. At that time, Bian Shao, the Chancellor of Chen, oversaw the state’s rites. Though his talent was modest and his thoughts shallow, unable to fathom the perfected one or distinguish right from wrong, he relied on written records to assert that Laozi embraced emptiness, guarded stillness, delighted in namelessness, upheld non-virtue, shunned high office, and found peace in lowly positions. He left Confucius with words of benevolence, fled the world to live in seclusion, changed his name and surname, and feared being recognized.

The sun marks time by brightness and darkness, the moon completes itself through waxing and waning. The origins of growth and decline, the gates of fortune and misfortune—heaven’s way despises fullness and favors humility. Thus, Laozi’s exaltation in the present and the sacrifices offered to him by the people of this age stem from his fleeing emolument and dwelling in obscurity, diminishing himself again and again, manifesting the purity of emptiness and non-being, existing before heaven and earth, preserving authenticity and nurturing nature, thereby attaining the Five Blessings.

With reverence, I compose and inscribe this, its words reading:

Ah, the mysterious power,
Embracing emptiness, guarding purity.
Delighting in lowly positions,
Holding office without scheming.
As a plumb line, it straightens;
Bent, it can coil.
Facing the Three Rivers,
He vented his grievances and scattered his indignation.
Perceiving the moment, he acted,
Waiting at the suburbs, he emerged radiant.
The fortune of reclusion,
Fleeing the world, concealing his name.
Holding to the One without fail,
Bringing peace to all under heaven.
Dwelling in thickness, not thinness,
Abiding in substance, containing glory.
Taking models as weighty,
Gold and jade as light.
Cutting off desires, abandoning cravings,
Returning to infancy.
Vastly traversing the ages,
None knew his true nature.
Essentially, through non-action,
Great transformation is accomplished.
Advancing and retreating without constancy,
Interweaving constancy within.
Taking knowledge as ignorance,
Empty yet not full.
The measure of the great man,
Beyond the judgment of the ordinary.
The ninth-rank scholar,
How could it burden his name?
Shining like the sun and moon,
Aligned with the Five Stars.
Entering and exiting the cinnabar chamber,
Ascending and descending the Yellow Court.
Turning his back on the vulgar,
Discarding splendor, concealing his form.
Enveloping the primordial, transforming spirit,
Inhaling and exhaling the purest essence.
The world could not fathom him,
Knowing neither his life nor death.
Celestial and human ranks offer sacrifices,
Illuminating his numinous power.
Admiring his extended years,
I carve this stone to honor him.

chunks.original_text: 十二月，再遣中常侍管霸诣苦县祀老君。 九年，建濯龙宫於芳林园，以文厨为坛，饰淳金扣音口器，设华盖之座，用郊天乐。 帝亲祀老君，以浮图释氏配享焉。 并见《后汉书》。 按束汉《西域传》云：天竺国一名身音乾毒，其国修浮屠道。 和帝时，遣使贡献。 至威帝延熹二年四月，频从日南缴外来献。 世传明帝梦见金人长大，项有光明，以问群臣，或日西方有神名日佛，其形长丈六尺而黄金色。 於是帝遣使之天竺问佛道法，於中国图画形像焉。 灵帝光和二年己未正月朔旦，老君敕太极真人三洞法师徐来勒等同降於天台山，老君乘八景玉舆，从官千万，正一真人侍焉。 老君自号太上玄一真人，真定光为洞经高玄法师，命侍仙玉郎王思真披九光玉报，出《洞玄大洞灵宝经》凡三十六部，以授仙人葛玄，及上清斋法二等，其一绝群独宴，静气仪刑，冥心之斋，入圣升虚之法也。 其二清坛肃倡，依按真仪，先拔九祖，次及家门，后谢己身也。 并三录七品斋法：三录者，金录斋调和阴阳，保镇国祚，玉录斋保佑后妃公侯贵族，黄录斋拔度九玄七祖，永辞长夜之苦。 七品者，日明真斋，超度幽爽，解诸冤对也。 日自然斋，普为众生请福谢罪，学仙修行之法也。 日三元斋，自谢犯戒之罪，解考於三官也。 日八节斋，谢玄祖及己身之罪，灭黑簿之法也。 日洞神斋，以精简为上，求仙保国之法也。 日指教斋，以清素为贵，救疾禳灾之法也。 日涂炭斋，以苦节为功，悔过请福之法也。 并《劝戒法轮经》四十五卷，《无量通妙》、《转神入定》等经以授玄，俾行化於世。 曰：子应常思虚无真人高上大法王大千世界号日老子，是玄中大法师焉。 玄字孝先，威帝延熹七年甲辰四月八日月，父汉为尚书。 玄始生，有支道纪者，高道之道，谓其父曰：吾昨闻通玄真人从大罗天下也，君家当为神仙宗伯，非常儿比。 其父曰：仙人变化不可测，愿得寿考以为宗嗣足矣。 玄大而秀颖，性识英明，经传子史靡不该览。 年十#4余岁，俱失恃估，忽叹曰：天下有常不死之道，何不学焉。 因遁迩名山，参访异人，服食芝木，得从仙人左慈受《九丹金液仙经》。 玄勤奉斋科，善治病劾鬼，兼吐纳导引，精思念道，故感老君亲降，授之经法。 又示以天府所定世人罪福条目，即《太上感应篇》。 又曰：功满三千，白日升天，修善有余，坐降云车。 弘道不已，自致不死。 玄稽首礼谢。 今天台山桐相观有法轮院三真经之处及仙公役鬼所筑受诘坛存焉。 昊赤乌二年戊午十月朔日甲子日中，老君命九天帝释持太上三天金简锡文赐玄为太极左仙公，其文曰：扬州丹阳郡句容县葛玄，先世苦行，累劫立功，损身布施，济度危亡，转轮圣域，炼神守精，志竭道源，事师恭肃，勤修匪懈，积感太上，注名玄都，上仙定籍。 是故英明智惠，诞降德门。 所以才质玉秀，馨兰清发，天姿逸颖，卓然挺拔，道谟渊伟，独步群萃，高辞世荣，抱朴尚质，注心真仙，含元守一，散发林薮，倚岩为室，得意山林，观此蓬华，过中不餐，斋不亏日，烧香诵经，拜礼靡缺，慈心度人，经营不辍，志穷微迹，大法周悉，教世贤愚，莫不解说，谦谦和颜，常怀欣悦。
chunks.translated_text:
In the twelfth month, the Emperor again dispatched the Palace Attendant Guan Ba to Ku County to offer sacrifices to Lord Lao. In the ninth year, he constructed the Zhuolong Palace within the Fanglin Garden, designating the literary chamber as an altar. He adorned it with pure gold clasps and sounding vessels, arranged a seat beneath a floral canopy, and employed the music of the suburban sacrifices. The Emperor personally worshipped Lord Lao, with the Buddhist figures of the Floating Image tradition as co-recipients of offerings. This is recorded in the *Book of Later Han*.

According to the *Account of the Western Regions* in the *Book of Eastern Han*: the kingdom of Tianzhu, also called Shenyin Gandhara, practiced the Dao of the Floating Image. During the reign of Emperor He, envoys were sent to offer tribute. By the second year of Emperor Huan’s Yanxi era, in the fourth month, they frequently arrived from beyond Rinan to present offerings.

Legend holds that Emperor Ming dreamed of a towering golden figure with a radiant halo around his neck. When he inquired of his ministers, one replied that in the West there was a deity named Buddha, whose form stood sixteen feet tall and shone like gold. Thereupon, the Emperor dispatched envoys to Tianzhu to inquire about the Buddha’s Dao and law, and had his image painted in China.

In the second year of Emperor Ling’s Guanghe era, on the first day of the first month of the year *jiwei*, Lord Lao commanded the Heavenly Emperor of the Nine Heavens to descend with the Three Caverns Dharma Master Xu Laile and others upon Mount Tiantai. Lord Lao rode in an eight-scene jade chariot, accompanied by ten thousand attendants, with the Orthodox Unity Perfected One in attendance. Lord Lao styled himself the Supreme Primordial Unity Perfected One, and appointed Zhen Dingguang as the High Mystery Dharma Master of the Cavern Scripture. He ordered the Jade Gentleman of the Immortal Attendants, Wang Sizhen, to unfurl the Nine Radiance Jade Report and present the *Cavern Mystery Great Cavern Numinous Treasure Scripture* in thirty-six sections to the immortal Ge Xuan, along with two grades of Upper Clarity purification rites.

The first was the secluded fast, where one severs worldly ties, cultivates stillness, and models the deportment of the void—entering sageliness and ascending emptiness. The second was the pure altar fast, where one reverently follows the true rites: first delivering the nine ancestors, then one’s household, and finally oneself.

These were the three registers and seven grades of purification rites: the three registers were the Gold Register fast, which harmonizes yin and yang and safeguards the nation’s destiny; the Jade Register fast, which protects empresses, consorts, dukes, and noble clans; and the Yellow Register fast, which delivers the nine lineages and seven ancestors, forever freeing them from the suffering of eternal night.

The seven grades were: the Sun Illuminating Perfection fast, which transcends the departed and resolves all karmic entanglements; the Sun Natural fast, which universally seeks blessings for sentient beings, atones for transgressions, and cultivates the Dao for immortality; the Three Primes fast, which atones for violations of precepts and resolves judgments before the Three Officials; the Eight Nodes fast, which repents the sins of one’s ancestors and oneself, erasing the Black Record; the Cavern Spirit fast, which values purity and simplicity as the highest, seeking immortality and protecting the nation; the Instruction fast, which esteems clarity and plainness, curing illnesses and averting calamities; and the Mud and Charcoal fast, which values austerity as merit, repenting transgressions and seeking blessings.

Along with these, he bestowed the *Sutra of the Wheel of Admonition and Precepts* in forty-five scrolls, the *Boundless Penetrating Mystery*, the *Turning Spirit into Samadhi*, and other scriptures upon Ge Xuan, charging him to propagate them in the world.

He declared: "You should constantly contemplate the Highest Great Dao King of the Vacuous Perfected One, the Lord of the Great Thousand Worlds, known as Laozi, who is the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center. Ge Xuan, styled Xiaoxian, was born in the seventh year of Emperor Huan’s Yanxi era, on the eighth day of the fourth month of the year *jiachen*. His father, Ge Han, served as a Secretary. When Xuan was born, a certain Zhi Daoji, a master of the lofty Dao, said to his father: 'Yesterday, I heard that the Master of Penetrating Mystery descended from the Great Canopy Heaven. Your family shall become the patriarchs of divine immortals—this child is no ordinary one.'

His father replied: 'The transformations of immortals are unfathomable. I would be content if he merely lived a long life as my heir.'

Xuan grew up refined and intelligent, his nature and understanding exceptionally bright. He perused all the classics, masters’ works, philosophers, and histories without exception. At the age of fourteen, having lost both parents, he suddenly sighed: 'The world possesses an eternal, deathless Dao—why not study it?' Thereupon, he wandered to renowned mountains, seeking out extraordinary persons. Ingesting the essence of mushrooms and trees, he received the *Scripture of the Nine Elixirs and Golden Liquid* from the immortal Zuo Ci.

Xuan diligently observed the purification precepts, excelled in healing illnesses and exorcising ghosts, and practiced breath control and guiding exercises. Through concentrated meditation on the Dao, he moved Lord Lao to descend personally and bestow upon him scriptures and methods. He also revealed the celestial court’s decrees on the karmic conditions of worldly beings, namely the *Tract on Response and Retribution*. He further said: 'When merit fills three thousand, one ascends to heaven in broad daylight. With surplus goodness, one descends seated upon a cloud chariot. Ceaselessly propagating the Dao, one attains deathlessness.'

Xuan bowed his head in reverence and gratitude.

Today, at the Tongxiang Abbey on Mount Tiantai, the site of the Dharma Wheel Courtyard where the Three Perfected Scriptures were transmitted, as well as the Interrogation Altar built by the immortal lord’s spirit laborers, still remain.

On the first day of the tenth month of the second year of Sun Hao’s Chiwu era, the day *jiazi* at noon, Lord Lao commanded the Heavenly Emperor of the Nine Heavens to present the Golden Tablet of the Supreme Three Heavens, bestowing upon Xuan the title of Left Immortal Duke of the Great Ultimate. The decree read:

'Ge Xuan of Jurong County in Danyang Commandery of Yangzhou: in past lives, you practiced austerities, accumulated merit over kalpas, sacrificed your body in almsgiving, and rescued those in peril. You turned the wheel of the sacred realm, refined spirit and preserved essence, exhausted your will in the source of the Dao, and served your master with reverence. Your diligent cultivation was unceasing, deeply moving the Supreme. Your name is inscribed in the Mysterious Capital, and your rank is fixed among the Upper Immortals. Thus, your wisdom and intelligence were born into a virtuous lineage. Your talents are jade-like and refined, your fragrance like orchids in bloom. Your celestial disposition is transcendent and outstanding, towering above the crowd. Your Daoist counsel is profound and majestic, unmatched among your peers. You renounced worldly glory, embraced simplicity, and upheld authenticity. You focused your heart on the true immortals, embraced the primordial and guarded the One. You let your hair loose in the forests and mountains, dwelling in a cliffside abode. Delighting in the mountains and forests, you contemplated the lotus blossoms. You fasted past noon, never missing a day of purification. You burned incense and recited scriptures, never neglecting your bows and rites. With a compassionate heart, you delivered others, tirelessly working for their salvation. Your will pursued the subtlest traces, and the great Dharma was thoroughly mastered. You taught both the wise and foolish, explaining all without exception. Humble and amiable, you always wore a joyful countenance.'"

chunks.original_text: 今锡子以丹锦绣被、飞罗之裙、天宝羽服、芙蓉晨冠、金真神虎仗、命魔婶，所为在意，役海召山。 玄索隐翻经，长斋静念，才思专精，苦而不倦，今锡子以八景玉舆，驾龙乘云，项生圆光，金章玉文，以酬昔德，世．为道门。 后贤仰止，秉持法轮。 太上尊教，三天所诠矣。 玄体德弘远，训化道俗，溥济群品，大度妙觉，功成得名高真信伏，巍巍上圣，皇皇穆穆，恩盈十方，各得所欲也，今锡子位为太上玉京太极左仙公，总统三界六天大魔王之官属，给真仙玉童、玉女各五百人侍直，左执九曜之香华，右擎太上洞玄之经，龙骑二千，游行上清九宫，一年三朝太上玄都玉京金阙，太上锡命，天帝承书奉行。 依法启行，如三天旧典。 时有沙门释道微、竺法兰者，远闻仙公得道，故来求师焉。 作礼请问曰：我闻道无先后，无古今，不审太上老子与悉达太子其道同异。 仙公曰：本无高下贵贱形名之殊。 乃於天台山立坛，授道微法兰《五岳真形图》告曰：太上传命之信，执之游八方名山，三界奉迎。 又以《太上金丹经》、《灵宝自然五称宝曜文》、《三皇内文大有妙经》、《天师旨教金书玉字》等凡十卷，并太极龙誊芝草一茎，告盟仙官，各令佩身，命入室弟子郑思远具宣口诀。 又惠以仙药一粒，令辟谷除五味之类，可以远游名山。 道微等既受宝经灵药，不饥不渴，愿得少留侍奉圣尊，仙公曰：子心存我，我即可见，不必依恋。 子应登嵩高，彼山诸真后五年复当传子秘诀，成子道矣。 仙公尝谓诸儒各讲明经论，张昭问：述而不作，信而好古，窃比於我老彭，其旨如何。 仙公曰：老子演自然之道，化行天下，孔子历聘诸国，仁及齐民，其归一揆。 太子登尝问仙公：庄周云：六合之外，圣人存而不论，六合之内，圣人论而不议，何也。 仙公曰：六合之内，囿於形象阴阳之数，犹可致请。 六合之外，人所希见，渺茫之中，太虚之表，圣人罔述，故存而不论也。 登称善。 七年甲子岁，仙公年八十一，八月十五日，太上命从官乘龙麟，执九光之节、景云之符，縿驾九龙八景云舆，垂荫华盖、龙婶虎旗来迎仙公，仙公飞辔云问，停驾太虚，作五言歌诗三篇以遣世人。 其一曰：真人昔遗教，愍念狐疑子，璧邪不信道，祸乱由斯起，身死而名灭，悔恨何所以。 罪大不可拚，流毒将谁理，冥冥未出期，劫尽庶当已。 转轮贫贱家，或复为役使。 六根或不完，整璧行乞市。 不知积罪报，怨天神不恃。 大道常无为，弘之由善始。 吾今巍巍尊，立功所得耳。 三界稽首礼，从容紫宫裹。 停驾虚空中，控龙飞凤峙。 临诀属素翰，粗标灵妙纪。 其二曰：我今便升天，依依诸儒英。 大道体虚无，寂寂中有精。 观者皆云昧，窈窈中昭明。 莫言道虚诞，所患不至诚。 奚不登名山，诵是洞真经。 一诵而一咏，玄音彻太清。 太上辉金容，众仙齐应声。 十方散香花，墦烟旗檀馨。 皇娥奏九韶，鸾凤仪哀呜。 龙驾翳空迎，华盖耀杳冥。 萧条劫仞表，帝释钦降庭。 八王奉丹液，抱濑身腾轻。 逍遥有无问，流朗人形名。 神童夹侍侧，自然朝万灵。 其三曰：飘飘八景舆，飞轮涉天京。 优游七宝宫，相与乐未英。 七祖升福堂，先贤亦获生。 王侯能信谨，终为天下贞。
chunks.translated_text:
Now bestowed upon you are crimson brocade robes, skirts of flying silk, celestial feathered garments, a lotus-dawn crown, the Golden Perfected Divine Tiger Staff, and the command of demonic maidservants—whatever you will, you may summon the seas and call forth the mountains.

For your profound studies of hidden scriptures, your long fasts and quiet contemplation, your focused and unwavering dedication, you are now granted the Eight Radiance Jade Chariot, to ride dragons and mount the clouds, with a halo of light encircling your neck, and golden seals with jade inscriptions, to repay your past virtues. Thus shall you be of the Daoist gate for generations to come. May later worthies look up to you, upholding the Dharma-wheel. The Most High’s venerable teachings are expounded by the Three Heavens.

Your embodiment of virtue is vast and far-reaching; you instruct and transform both Daoists and laity, universally aiding all beings. Your great attainment of wondrous enlightenment has earned you a name among the lofty perfected, and even the mighty demons submit in reverence. O towering sage, radiant and majestic, your grace fills the ten directions, and all beings attain their desires. Now you are bestowed the rank of Most High Jade Capital Supreme Left Immortal Lord, overseeing the officials and retinues of the Six Heavens and the Great Demon Kings of the Three Realms. You are granted five hundred jade lads and five hundred jade maidens as attendants, bearing in your left hand the incense and flowers of the Nine Luminaries, and in your right the *Supreme Cavern Mystery Scriptures* of the Most High. With two thousand dragon-riders, you shall roam the Nine Palaces of the Upper Clarity, thrice a year ascending to the Golden Towers of the Jade Capital in the Supreme Mystery Metropolis. The Most High confers this mandate, and the Heavenly Emperor receives the decree to carry it out. Proceed according to the ancient statutes of the Three Heavens.

At that time, the śramaṇas Śākyamuni’s disciple Daowei and Zhu Falan, having heard from afar of the Immortal Lord’s attainment, came to seek him as their teacher. They bowed and inquired: “We have heard that the Dao has no before or after, no past or present. We wonder whether the Most High Lord Lao and Prince Siddhārtha’s paths are the same or different.”

The Immortal Lord replied: “In essence, there is no distinction of high or low, noble or base, form or name.”

Thereupon, he established an altar on Mount Tiantai and transmitted to Daowei and Falan the *Chart of the Five Sacred Peaks’ True Forms*, saying: “This is the token of the Most High’s command. Carry it as you travel to the famous mountains of the eight directions, and the Three Realms shall welcome you.” He also bestowed upon them the *Most High Golden Elixir Scripture*, the *Five Spontaneous Treasures of the Numinous Jewels*, the *Three Sovereigns’ Inner Writ of the Great Existence*, the *Celestial Master’s Golden Book of Jade Characters*, and other texts totaling ten scrolls, along with a stalk of *taiji* dragon-script magic fungus. He charged the immortal officials to wear them on their persons and commanded his chamber disciple Zheng Siyuan to impart the oral instructions in full. He further gifted them a grain of immortal medicine, enabling them to abstain from grains and forsake the five flavors, so they might wander freely among the famous mountains.

Daowei and the others, having received the sacred scriptures and divine medicine, felt neither hunger nor thirst. They wished to remain a while longer to serve the sagely master, but the Immortal Lord said: “If your heart holds me, I shall always be visible to you. There is no need for attachment. You should ascend Mount Song; after five years, the perfected ones of that mountain will transmit to you the secret instructions, and your Dao shall be accomplished.”

The Immortal Lord once remarked to the various Confucians discussing the classics: Zhang Zhao asked, “‘Transmitting but not creating, trusting and loving the ancients, I humbly compare myself to Old Peng’—what is the meaning of this?” The Immortal Lord replied: “Laozi expounded the Dao of spontaneity, transforming the world, while Confucius journeyed through the states, extending benevolence to the people. Their ultimate aim is one and the same.”

Taizi Deng once asked the Immortal Lord: “Zhuangzi said, ‘Beyond the Six Directions, the sage acknowledges but does not discuss; within the Six Directions, the sage discusses but does not debate.’ Why is this?” The Immortal Lord replied: “Within the Six Directions, bound by forms, images, and the reckonings of yin and yang, one may still make inquiries. Beyond the Six Directions, where human sight rarely reaches, in the vastness beyond the void, the sage refrains from discourse, hence ‘acknowledges but does not discuss.’” Deng praised this answer.

In the *jiazi* year of the seventh cycle, at the age of eighty-one, on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, the Most High commanded his attendants to ride dragon-unicorns, bearing the Nine Radiance Staff and the Cloud Banner, harnessing nine dragons and the Eight Radiance Cloud Chariot, with canopies of blossoming shade and banners of dragon maidens and tiger flags, to welcome the Immortal Lord. The Immortal Lord reined in his cloud steed, halting his chariot in the Great Void, and composed three five-character poems to leave behind for the world.

The first:
*The perfected of old left teachings,*
*Moved by those lost in doubt.*
*Those who reject the Dao for heresy*
*Bring calamity upon themselves.*
*When the body dies and the name perishes,*
*What regret can there be?*
*Great sins cannot be absolved;*
*Who shall purge this poison?*
*In the unseen, the time of emergence is unknown;*
*Only when the kalpa ends may it cease.*
*Reincarnated in poor and lowly families,*
*Some become servants again.*
*With senses impaired or incomplete,*
*They beg in the marketplace like broken jade.*
*Unaware of the retribution for accumulated sins,*
*They blame the gods and resent Heaven.*
*The Great Dao is ever non-action;*
*Its vastness begins with goodness.*
*Now I, towering and revered,*
*Have earned this through my deeds.*
*The Three Realms bow in homage;*
*I dwell at ease within the Purple Palace.*
*Halting my chariot in the void,*
*I rein in dragons and phoenixes.*
*At parting, I leave these plain words,*
*Roughly outlining the wondrous record.*

The second:
*Now I ascend to Heaven,*
*Leaving behind the scholars with reluctance.*
*The Great Dao embodies emptiness and nothingness,*
*Yet within stillness, essence resides.*
*Those who observe call it obscure,*
*But within the profound, clarity shines.*
*Do not say the Dao is empty and false;*
*The fault lies in lack of sincerity.*
*Why not climb the famous mountains*
*And recite the* Cavern Real Scriptures*?*
*With each recitation and chant,*
*The mysterious sound pierces the Great Clarity.*
*The Most High’s golden countenance radiates;*
*The assembled immortals respond in unison.*
*From the ten directions, incense and flowers scatter;*
*Banners of fragrant sandalwood smoke rise.*
*The Royal Consort plays the Nine Shao;*
*Phoenixes and simurghs sing mournfully.*
*Dragon chariots obscure the sky in welcome;*
*Canopies gleam in the distant void.*
*Beyond the desolation of the kalpa’s measure,*
*The Lord of Śakra descends to the courtyard in reverence.*
*The Eight Kings offer the cinnabar elixir;*
*Embracing the current, their bodies become light.*
*Carefree, they wander beyond being and non-being,*
*Illuminating the names and forms of humanity.*
*Divine lads attend on either side;*
*Spontaneously, they pay homage to the myriad spirits.*

The third:
*Soaring in the Eight Radiance Chariot,*
*The flying wheels traverse the Celestial Capital.*
*Wandering leisurely in the Seven Treasures Palace,*
*Together we delight in eternal splendor.*
*Seven generations of ancestors ascend to the Hall of Blessings;*
*Former worthies, too, attain rebirth.*
*Kings and lords who are faithful and reverent*
*Shall ultimately become the world’s pillars.*
*If you can uphold sincerity,*
*You too shall ascend to the heavens.*

chunks.original_text: 大人体至德，一切蒙其成。 散诞游山水，吐纳和灵津。 练气同希夷，静咏《道德》篇。 一心柄玄漠，冥感今乃宣。 飞驾辔九龙，飘飘乘紫烟。 暂迂蓬莱宫，倏忽已升天。 伟伟众真会，眇眇凌虚玄。 体固无终劫，金颜随日鲜。 若人弘众妙，轻举升神仙。 歌毕，云舆冉冉升天而去。 魏陈留王时咸熙元年甲申，老君降现於陇右临洮郡襄武县，身长三丈，着白衣，垂素发，戴金冠，告县人王始曰：天下不久当太平。 及武帝受禅，果天下一统，帝乃令於所现处造太平观，即李宗之故居也。 见《晋书》。 昊兴戴洋年十二时，死五日而苏，说死时天使为酒吏，授符线，给吏从，磨麾将上蓬莱、混仑、积石、太室、常、庐、衡等·诸山，既而被谪遣归。 洋自此好道术，妙解占候卜数。 昊末为台吏，知昊将亡，托病不仕。 尝至濑乡，经老子祠，追思境物，皆是洋昔死时所见处，因问守藏应凤曰：去二十年前，尝有人乘马束行，过老君祠不下马，未达桥而坠马死者不。 凤言有之，所问之事悉与洋同。 盖洋由此被谴而谪还人世也。 道士梁谌修道於楼观，精思积年。 晋惠帝永兴二年乙丑五月五日，老君命太和真人尹轨降其室，授以炼气隐形之法、《日月黄华上经》、《水石还丹》、《六甲秘符》等经，谌遂能飞行变化。 三年丹成，白日升天。 后魏道武皇帝好《老子》言，诵咏不倦，数召诸王及朝臣亲为说之。 天兴中，仪曹郎董谧因献《服食仙经》数十篇，於是置仙人博士。 晋安帝天兴元年壬寅，姚秦之洪始五年，仙人成公兴因行秦土，遇道士寇谦之，遂师事之，乃隐居华岳。 山神忽见，告公兴曰：老君将下按行山岳，子可加斋勤修。 公兴惕然加勤香火，仰候天文。 十一月二十三日戊子夜，北斗魁中紫阳文昌赫然而开，乃见老君乘白麟冉冉而下，足蹑莲花，双幢举高三丈，侍从仙人玉女甚众。 老君临驾顾救公兴曰：汝今游处中岳，可得仙度。 公兴再拜，起已不见。 明年癸卯二月，乃依所救上日其师寇谦之，遂同过关往嵩高少室居焉。 老君又降河南谷水里，停驾空中，语公兴曰：吾去岁於华山束崖，今汝来居嵩镇，子自到此，意复如何。 公兴稽首礼谢，老君曰：嵩少河洛，集仙之府，游龙之渊，不可远去。 即敕玉女取药赐公兴。 公兴再拜，跪而服之。 老君曰：子服吾药，补填五脏，神心开朗，无不通鉴矣。 昔以张道陵继天师并代干吉，道陵升天之后，鬼魔复作，中国统绝，非子师谁可任也。 见《后魏书》。 按《后魏释老志》云：世祖时，道士寇谦之字辅真，南雍州刺史赞之弟，寇佝之十三世孙。 早好仙道，有绝俗之心，少修张鲁之卫，服食饵药，历年无效，幽诚上达。 有仙人成公兴，不知何许人，至谦之·从母家佣赁。 谦之尝觐其姨，见公兴形貌甚强，力作不倦，请回赁公兴代己使役。 乃将还，令其开合南棘田。 谦之树下坐算，公兴恳发致勤，时来看算，谦之谓云：汝但力作，何为看此。 二三日后，复来看之，如此不已。 后谦之算七曜有所不了，惘然自失，公兴谓谦之曰：先生何为不悍。 谦之曰：我学算累年，而近算《周脾》不合，以此自愧。 且非汝所知，何劳问也。 公兴曰：先生试随公兴语布之。 俄然便次，谦之叹伏，不测公兴之深浅，请师事之。
chunks.translated_text:
The Great One embodies the supreme virtue,
All things beneath receive its completion.
Roaming freely through mountains and rivers,
Exhaling and inhaling the numinous essence.
Refining qi in union with the subtle and serene,
Silently chanting the *Dao and Virtue* chapters.
With single-minded grasp of the mysterious void,
Hidden resonance now manifests in full.

Riding a chariot drawn by nine dragons,
Lightly ascending on purple mist.
A brief sojourn at Penglai Palace—
In an instant, already ascended to heaven.
Majestic, the assembly of perfected beings;
Vast and distant, they traverse the empty mystery.
Their bodies endure beyond kalpas,
Golden countenances ever fresh as the sun.

Should one fathom the manifold wonders,
Lightly they rise as divine immortals.

The song concluded, the cloud-borne chariot slowly ascended into heaven and departed.

In the first year of Xianxi of the Chenliu King of Wei, the jiashen year, Lord Lao descended and appeared in Longyou’s Lintao Commandery, Xiangwu County. His body stood thirty feet tall, clad in white robes, with flowing silver hair and a golden crown. He addressed Wang Shi of the county, saying: “The world shall soon attain Great Peace.” When Emperor Wu received the abdication, the realm was indeed unified, and he ordered the construction of the Taiping Abbey at the site of the apparition—formerly the residence of Li Zong.

As recorded in the *Book of Jin*:
Dai Yang of Wuxing was twelve years old when he died and revived after five days. He recounted that in death, a celestial envoy appointed him as wine steward, bestowing upon him a tally and thread, along with attendants and a banner-bearing retinue. He was led to ascend Penglai, Kunlun, Jishi, Taishi, Chang, Lu, Heng, and other sacred mountains, only to be later demoted and sent back. Thereafter, Dai Yang developed a passion for the Daoist arts, mastering divination, astrology, and numerology. At the end of the Wu dynasty, he served as a court scribe but foresaw the dynasty’s fall and feigned illness to avoid office. Once, passing through Lai Xiang, he visited the shrine of Lord Lao. The landscape stirred memories—all was as he had seen in death. He asked the shrine keeper, Ying Feng: “Over twenty years ago, was there a man who rode past the shrine of Lord Lao without dismounting, only to fall from his horse and die before reaching the bridge?” Feng confirmed the event, and all details matched Dai Yang’s account. Thus it became clear that he had been sent back to the mortal realm as a punishment.

The Daoist Liang Chen cultivated the Dao at Louguan, refining his spirit for years. In the second year of Yongxing of Emperor Huai of Jin, the yichou year, on the fifth day of the fifth month, Lord Lao commanded the Perfected One of Grand Harmony, Yin Gui, to descend to his chamber. There, he transmitted the methods of refining qi and concealing one’s form, along with the *Sun and Moon Yellow Splendor Upper Scripture*, *Water and Stone Returned Elixir*, *Six Jia Secret Talismans*, and other scriptures. Liang Chen thereafter gained the ability to fly and transform. Three years later, his elixir perfected, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

Later, Emperor Daowu of Northern Wei revered the words of *Laozi*, reciting them tirelessly. He frequently summoned princes and ministers to personally expound its teachings. During the Tianxing era, the Gentleman of Ceremonies, Dong Mi, presented dozens of *Scriptures on Ingesting Immortality Elixirs*, prompting the establishment of the post of Immortal Studies Academician.

In the first year of Tianxing of Emperor An of Jin, the renyin year—the fifth year of Hong Shi of Yao Qin—the immortal Cheng Gongxing traveled through Qin territory and encountered the Daoist Kou Qianzhi. He became Kou’s disciple and retreated to Mount Hua. Suddenly, the mountain spirit appeared, telling Gongxing: “Lord Lao is about to descend and inspect the sacred peaks. You should intensify your purification and devotion.” Gongxing, struck with awe, redoubled his incense offerings and gazed heavenward in anticipation.

On the twenty-third day of the eleventh month, the wuzi night, the Purple Yang and Wen Chang constellations within the Dipper’s bowl blazed open. Lord Lao descended upon a white qilin, his feet treading lotus blossoms. A pair of banners rose thirty feet high, attended by a throng of perfected immortals and jade maidens. As his chariot alighted, Lord Lao turned to Gongxing and said: “You now dwell upon the Central Marchmount; you shall attain immortal deliverance.” Gongxing bowed twice, and when he rose, Lord Lao had vanished.

The following year, the guimao year, in the second month, he relayed the appointed day to his master, Kou Qianzhi. Together, they passed through the pass and settled on the heights of Mount Song’s Shaoshi Peak.

Lord Lao descended again in the Gushui hamlet of Henan, halting his chariot in midair. He addressed Gongxing: “Last year, I appeared on the eastern cliffs of Mount Hua. Now you have come to reside in the Song-Shao region. Since arriving here, what are your thoughts?” Gongxing prostrated himself in reverence. Lord Lao said: “The Song and Shaoshi peaks, the Yellow and Luo rivers—this is the abode of immortals, the abyss of soaring dragons. You must not depart far.” He then commanded a jade maiden to fetch medicine and bestow it upon Gongxing. Gongxing bowed twice, knelt, and consumed it. Lord Lao said: “By ingesting my medicine, your five viscera shall be replenished, your divine mind illuminated, and nothing shall escape your perception. Formerly, I appointed Zhang Daoling as Celestial Master, succeeding Gan Ji. After Zhang Daoling ascended to heaven, demonic forces resurged, and the orthodox lineage of China was severed. Who but your master is fit for this task?”

As recorded in the *Book of Later Wei*:
According to the *Treatise on Buddhism and Daoism* in the *Book of Wei*, during the reign of Emperor Shizu, the Daoist Kou Qianzhi, styled Fuzhen, was the younger brother of Kou Zan, the Governor of Nanyang Commandery, and a thirteenth-generation descendant of Kou Gou. From youth, he harbored a passion for immortality and a heart detached from the mundane. In his early years, he practiced the arts of Zhang Lu, ingesting elixirs and medicinal herbs for years without effect. Yet his hidden sincerity reached the heavens.

There was an immortal named Cheng Gongxing, of unknown origin, who came to work as a hired laborer at the home of Kou Qianzhi’s maternal aunt. When Qianzhi visited his aunt, he saw Gongxing—robust in appearance, tireless in labor—and requested to take him on as a replacement servant. He brought Gongxing home and tasked him with clearing the southern thorn fields. Qianzhi sat beneath a tree, calculating, while Gongxing labored diligently, occasionally glancing at the calculations. Qianzhi said: “Just focus on your work. Why do you keep looking at this?” After two or three days, Gongxing returned to observe again, and this continued repeatedly. Later, Qianzhi encountered difficulties in calculating the seven luminaries and was lost in confusion. Gongxing asked: “Master, why are you troubled?” Qianzhi replied: “I have studied calculation for years, yet recently my *Zhou Bi* calculations fail to align. I am ashamed of this. It is not something you would understand, so why ask?” Gongxing said: “Master, try arranging them as I instruct.” In an instant, the calculations fell into place. Qianzhi marveled, unable to fathom Gongxing’s depth, and begged to become his disciple.

chunks.original_text: 公兴固辞不肯，但求为谦之弟子。 未几，谓之曰：先生有意学道，岂能与公兴隐遁乎。 谦之欣然从之。 公兴乃令谦之洁斋三日，共入华山，令谦之居一石室，自出探药还与谦之。 谦之食药，不复饥。 乃将谦之入嵩山，有三重石室，令谦之住第二重。 历年，公兴谓谦之曰：公兴出后，当有人将药来，但得食之，莫为疑怪。 寻有人将药至，皆是毒虫臭恶之物，谦之大惧出走。 公兴还，问状，谦之具对，公兴欺惜曰：先生未便得仙，止可为帝王师耳。 公兴事谦之七年，忽谓谦之曰：公兴不得久留，明日中午当去。 公兴亡后，先生幸为沐浴，自当有人见迎。 公兴乃入第三重石室而卒。 谦之躬自沐浴，明日日中，有叩石室者，谦之出视见，两童子一持法服，一持钵及杖，谦之引入至公兴尸所，公兴钦然而起，着#5衣持钵执杖而去。 先是，有京兆灞城人王胡儿，其叔父亡，颇有灵异，曾将胡儿至嵩高别岭，同行观望，见金室玉堂，有一馆尤珍丽，空而无人，题日成公兴之馆。 胡儿怪而问之，其叔父曰：此是仙人成公兴馆，坐失火烧七问屋，被谪为寇谦之弟子七年。 始知谦之精诚远通，公兴乃仙者，谪满而去。 公兴事谦之凡七年而仙去，谦之守志嵩高，精专不懈。 元魏明元皇帝神瑞二年十月乙卯，忽有二神人衣翠羽之衣，冠紫金之冠，乘龙持节告谦之曰：太上老君至矣。 须臾，闻音乐之声渐近，仰望见玉衡车一乘，金刚为轮，胶驾九龙，威仪赫奕，神仙导从弥满虚空，集止山巅，仙官五人侍立於前。 谦之见有五官门忽然而开，仙乐交奏，坐白银花之座，敕仙伯王方平引谦之前立，谓曰：往辛亥年吾得嵩岳镇灵集仙宫主赵洪政等表云：自天师张道陵去世以来，地上旷职修善之人无所师授，以卿立身直理，行合自然，才任轨范，堪处师位，故来观汝，授汝天师之任，赐汝《云中音诵新科之戒》。 吾有经戒，自开辟以来不传於世，今运数应出，汝宜宣吾新科，清整吾教，佐国扶命，以化群生，除去三张之弊、租米税钱及男女合气之术。 时老君停驾云中三日，赐谦之经戒凡九卷，专以礼度为首，而加之以服气闭炼。 又遣玉女长容等十二人，教以服气导引之诀。 自是气盛体轻，颜色殊丽。 太常二年丁巳正月十五日，老君再降，赐以新科符录七十卷，号日并进。 八年癸亥岁十月十五日，又遣玄孙上师真人牧土宫主李普文降嵩岳，延谦之入仙宫，授以天宫太真太宝九州真师、治鬼师、化 民师、继天师等四录，及赐仙冕天衣、符录图文并坛治，又授以《太平素经》一百卷，皆真文大字，上师手书，令以甲子年奉经入国行化。 又赐以天果六枚，食之遂绝火食。 见《后魏释老志》。 按《后魏释老志》云：李普文，老君之玄孙，昔居代郡桑乾，以汉武之世得道为牧土官主，领治三十六土人鬼之政，地方十八万里有奇，盖历衍一章之数也。 其中为方万里者有三百六十，嵩岳所统广汉平土方万里，以授谦之。 作诰曰：吾处天官敷演真法处，汝道年二十二岁，除十年为童蒙，其余十二年教化，虽无大功，且有指授之劳，今赐汝迁入内官太真太宝九州真师、治鬼师、化民师、继天师四录，修动不懈，依劳复迁赐汝天中二真太文录，劾召百神，以授弟子。

Gongxing firmly declined, insisting only on becoming Qianzhi’s disciple. Before long, he said to him: “Master, if you truly intend to study the Dao, could you follow Gongxing into reclusion?” Qianzhi joyfully agreed. Gongxing then instructed Qianzhi to purify himself through fasting for three days, after which they entered Mount Hua. There, Gongxing had Qianzhi reside in a stone chamber while he went out to gather herbs, returning to give them to Qianzhi. After consuming the herbs, Qianzhi no longer felt hunger. Later, Gongxing took Qianzhi to Mount Song, where three layered stone chambers stood, and had him dwell in the second. After some years, Gongxing said to Qianzhi: “After I depart, someone will bring you medicine—simply consume it without doubt or fear.” Soon after, someone arrived with medicine, but it consisted of venomous insects and foul-smelling things. Terrified, Qianzhi fled. When Gongxing returned and inquired, Qianzhi recounted what had happened. Gongxing sighed in regret: “Master, you are not yet ready for immortality—you may only become a teacher to emperors.” Gongxing served Qianzhi for seven years before suddenly declaring: “I cannot stay much longer. Tomorrow at noon, I shall depart.” After Gongxing’s passing, he instructed Qianzhi to bathe himself, saying that someone would come to receive him. Gongxing then entered the third stone chamber and died. Qianzhi personally performed the ablutions. The next day at noon, someone knocked at the stone chamber. When Qianzhi emerged, he saw two youths—one holding ritual robes, the other a bowl and staff. He led them to Gongxing’s body, whereupon Gongxing rose upright, donned the robes, took the bowl and staff, and departed.

Earlier, a man from Baocheng in Jingzhao named Wang Hu’er had lost his uncle, who possessed extraordinary spiritual powers. The uncle once took Hu’er to a separate ridge of Mount Song, where they gazed upon a vision of golden halls and jade chambers. Among them stood a particularly resplendent pavilion, empty and unoccupied, inscribed with the words: *Hall of Cheng Gongxing*. Perplexed, Hu’er asked about it, and his uncle replied: “This is the hall of the immortal Cheng Gongxing. Once, he lost seven rooms in a fire and was demoted to serve as Kou Qianzhi’s disciple for seven years.” Only then did they realize that Qianzhi’s sincerity had reached far, and that Gongxing was indeed an immortal who, having completed his sentence, had departed.

Gongxing served Qianzhi for seven years before ascending as an immortal, while Qianzhi remained on Mount Song, steadfast and unwavering in his devotion. In the tenth month of the second year of the *Shenrui* era of Emperor Mingyuan of the Northern Wei, on the day *yimao*, two divine beings suddenly appeared before Qianzhi. Clad in kingfisher-feathered robes and crowned with purple-gold diadems, they rode dragons and bore tablets, announcing: “The Most High Lord Lao has arrived.” Soon after, the sound of celestial music drew near. Looking up, Qianzhi saw a jade-hubbed chariot, its wheels forged of *vajra*, drawn by nine dragons, its majesty resplendent. Divine attendants filled the void, and the procession alighted upon the mountain’s peak. Five immortal officials stood in attendance before him. Qianzhi witnessed the sudden opening of five celestial gates, celestial music resounding as the Most High Lord Lao sat upon a silver-flowered throne. He commanded the immortal minister Wang Fangping to bring Qianzhi forward and stand before him, saying: “In the year *xinhai*, I received a memorial from Zhao Hongzheng, the *Zhenling* Governor of the Immortal Assembly of Mount Song’s Sacred Peak, stating: ‘Since the passing of Celestial Master Zhang Daoling, those on earth who cultivate goodness have lacked a teacher. As you embody upright principle and conduct in harmony with nature, your talents suit you to serve as a model. You are thus fit to assume the role of teacher.’ I have come to observe you and now appoint you to the office of Celestial Master, bestowing upon you the *Yunzhong Yinsong Xinke Zhi Jie* (New Precepts of the Cloud-Chanting Rites). I possess scriptures and precepts, hidden since the dawn of time, which now, by the turning of fate, must be revealed. You shall proclaim my new precepts, rectify my teachings, assist the state and sustain the mandate, transforming the multitudes. Abolish the corruptions of the Three Zhangs—the levies of grain and coin, and the arts of yin-yang union.”

The Most High Lord Lao lingered in the clouds for three days, bestowing upon Qianzhi nine scrolls of scriptures and precepts, with ritual propriety as their foundation, supplemented by the practices of *qi*-absorption and inner refinement. He also dispatched twelve jade maidens, including Changrong, to teach him the secrets of *qi*-absorption and guiding-and-pulling. Thereafter, Qianzhi’s *qi* flourished, his body grew light, and his complexion became radiant.

On the fifteenth day of the first month of the second year of the *Taichang* era, the year *dingsi*, the Most High Lord Lao descended again, bestowing seventy scrolls of new precepts and talismans, collectively titled *Bingjin* (Simultaneous Advancement). In the eighth year of the *Guihai* era, on the fifteenth day of the tenth month, he further dispatched his great-great-grandson, the Perfected Master of the Pastoral Palace, Li Puwen, to descend upon Mount Song and summon Qianzhi into the immortal palace. There, he conferred upon Qianzhi the four registers of *Tian’gong Taizhen Taibao Jiuzhou Zhenshi* (Celestial Palace’s Supreme Perfected and Treasured Master of the Nine Provinces), *Zhigui Shi* (Master of Governing Spirits), *Huamin Shi* (Master of Transforming the People), and *Jitian Shi* (Successor to the Celestial Master), along with immortal crowns, celestial robes, talismans, charts, and altar rituals. He also bestowed the *Taiping Sujing* (Fundamental Scripture of Great Peace) in one hundred scrolls, all inscribed in authentic celestial script with large characters, personally transcribed by the Perfected Master. He commanded Qianzhi to present the scriptures to the state and propagate their teachings in the year *jiazi*. Additionally, he granted six celestial fruits, the consumption of which allowed Qianzhi to abstain from cooked food.

As recorded in the *Wei Shu: Shilao Zhi* (History of the Wei: Treatise on Buddhism and Daoism), Li Puwen was a great-great-grandson of the Most High Lord Lao. Formerly residing in Sanggan of Daijun, he attained the Dao during the reign of Emperor Wu of Han and became the Master of the Pastoral Palace, governing the administration of thirty-six earthly spirits and humans, with a domain spanning over 180,000 *li*—a number extending through one cycle of the *He* (River Chart). Within this domain, there were 360 regions, each spanning ten thousand *li*. Mount Song’s jurisdiction encompassed the vast and level lands of Guanghan, which were entrusted to Qianzhi. He issued a proclamation: “I reside in the Celestial Palace, expounding the true Dharma. You, at the age of twenty-two, have spent ten years in youthful ignorance, leaving twelve years for teaching and transformation. Though your merits are not yet great, you have labored in instruction. Now, I promote you to the inner office of *Taizhen Taibao Jiuzhou Zhenshi* (Supreme Perfected and Treasured Master of the Nine Provinces), *Zhigui Shi* (Master of Governing Spirits), *Huamin Shi* (Master of Transforming the People), and *Jitian Shi* (Successor to the Celestial Master). Persevere without slackening, and in accordance with your efforts, I shall further promote you, bestowing the *Tianzhong Erzhen Taiwen Lu* (Register of the Supreme Script of the Two Perfected Ones of the Celestial Center), enabling you to summon and command the hundred spirits and transmit them to your disciples.”

chunks.original_text: 文录有五等，一日阴阳太官，二日正府真官，三日正房真官，四日宿官散官，五日并进录生。 坛位礼拜，衣冠仪式，各有差品，几六十余卷，号日《录图真经》，付汝奉持，辅佐北方太平真君。 出天官静轮之法，能兴造克就，则超真仙矣。 又地上生民来劫垂及其中，行教甚难，但令男女立坛宇，朝夕礼拜。 若家有严君，功及上世，其中能修身炼药、学长生之卫，即为真君种民。 药别授方销炼金丹云英八十三浆之法，皆有诀要。 上师李君手笔有数篇，其余皆正真书曹赵道覆所书。 古文写边，篆隶杂体，辞义约辨，婉而成章，大旨与世礼相准，择贤推德信者为先，勤者次之。 又言二仪之间有三十六天，有三十六官，官有一主，最高者无极至尊，次日至大真尊，次天覆地载阴阳真尊，次洪正真尊，姓赵名道隐，以殷时得道，牧土之师也。 牧土之来，赤松、王乔之伦及韩终、张安世、刘根、张陵近世仙者，并为翼从。 牧土命谦之为弟子，与群神仙结为徒友。 幽冥之事世所不了，谦之一一告焉。 太武皇帝始光元年甲子岁，师遵教敕奉其书献之，四方翕然归向，而朝廷犹未全信。 司徒崔浩，博达之士也，奇其言，因师事之，遂上疏曰：臣闻圣人受命则天瑞应，而河图、洛书皆寄言於虫兽之文，未若今日神人对接，手笔灿然，辞旨深妙，自古无有。 昔汉高祖虽复大圣，四皓犹不屈节，今清德隐仙不召而至，斯诚陛下伴踪轩黄应天之符也，岂可以世常谈而忽上灵之命乎。 臣切惧之。 帝欣然嘉纳，即命有司诣山奠币，因迎致其余弟子在山中者。

The *Lu* (Registers) comprise five ranks: first, the *Yinyang Taiguan* (Grand Offices of Yin and Yang); second, the *Zhengfu Zhenguan* (Perfected Offices of the Rightful Courts); third, the *Zhengfang Zhenguan* (Perfected Offices of the Rightful Chambers); fourth, the *Suguan Sanguan* (Officials of the Lodged and Dispersed); and fifth, the *Bingjin Lusheng* (Concurrent Disciples of the Registers). The altar positions, rites of obeisance, vestments, and ceremonial forms each follow graded distinctions, totaling over sixty scrolls, collectively titled the *Lutu Zhenjing* (True Scripture of Registers and Charts). These I entrust to you for reverent observance, that you may assist the *Taiping Zhenjun* (Supreme Perfected Lord of Great Peace) of the Northern Realm.

The method of the *Tian’guan Jinglun* (Tranquil Wheel of the Celestial Offices) enables one to undertake and complete constructions, thereby transcending to the rank of True Immortal. Yet the people of the world now face the descent of the kalpa’s decline, making the propagation of the teachings exceedingly difficult. Simply instruct men and women to establish altars and perform morning and evening rites of obeisance. If a household has a stern patriarch, his merit extends to former generations; among them, those who cultivate the body, refine the elixir, and study the arts of longevity become the *Zhongmin* (Seed People) of the True Lords.

The methods for preparing medicines—including the formulas for refining the Golden Elixir and the Eighty-Three Nectars of *Yunying* (Cloud Radiance)—each possess essential secrets. Several chapters were inscribed by the hand of the Supreme Master Li Jun, while the remainder were written by the Perfected Scribe Zhao Daofu of the Rightful True Bureau. The ancient script is inscribed along the margins, interspersed with seal and clerical scripts, its phrases concise yet discerning, graceful and well-wrought. Its overarching principles align with the rites of the world, prioritizing those of virtue and trustworthiness, with the diligent following thereafter.

It further states that between the Two Modes (Heaven and Earth) lie the Thirty-Six Heavens, each governed by one of the Thirty-Six Offices. The highest of these is the *Wuji Zhizun* (Ultimate Venerable One), followed by the *Zhida Zhenzun* (Supreme Perfected Venerable One), then the *Tianfu Dizai Yinyang Zhenzun* (Perfected Venerable One of Heaven’s Cover and Earth’s Support, of Yin and Yang), and next the *Hongzheng Zhenzun* (Venerable One of Vast Rectitude), whose surname is Zhao and given name Daoyin. He attained the Dao during the Yin dynasty and is the Master of *Musu* (Pastoral Earth). Since the advent of *Musu*, the company of immortals—including *Chisong* (Red Pine), *Wang Qiao*, *Han Zhong*, *Zhang Anshi*, *Liu Gen*, and *Zhang Ling*—along with more recent transcendents, have all served as his attendants.

*Musu* commanded Qian to become his disciple, binding him in fraternal fellowship with the host of divine immortals. Matters of the netherworld, which the world does not comprehend, Qian explained to them one by one. In the first year of the *Shiguang* reign (jiazi year) of Emperor Taiwu, the Master, obeying the edict, presented these writings to the court. The four directions responded with unanimous reverence, though the imperial court had not yet fully embraced them. The Minister of Education, Cui Hao—a scholar of vast learning—marveled at the teachings and accordingly became the Master’s disciple. He then memorialized the throne, stating:

*“I have heard that when a sage receives the Mandate of Heaven, auspicious omens respond. Yet the* He Tu *and* Luo Shu *conveyed their messages through the patterns of beasts and insects—nothing compares to the present encounter between divine and mortal, where the Master’s hand has inscribed resplendent words of profound and wondrous import, unparalleled since antiquity. Though Emperor Gaozu of Han was a paragon of sagacity, the Four Hoary Ones still refused to bend their principles. Now, a transcendent of pure virtue has arrived unbidden—this is truly the celestial sign that Your Majesty walks in the footsteps of the Yellow Emperor and Fuxi, answering Heaven’s decree. How can such a divine mandate be dismissed as mere worldly discourse?”*

The Emperor joyfully approved and accepted the memorial, promptly ordering officials to journey to the mountain, present offerings, and welcome the remaining disciples dwelling there.

chunks.original_text: 帝见师不食，甚加礼敬。 又见符录，心弥钦信，乃建玄都坛，起静轮天宫，依仪大会。 师与弟子皆服仙衣天冠，光仪璀璨。 帝欲授师洎弟子以高爵，皆确辞不受，乃处以方外之礼。 敕师及门弟并列在王公之上，不听，称臣。 於是显扬新法，宣布天下，大阐清静无为之化。 别择大家子弟有德业者一百二十人为道士。 十七年庚辰，师於高岳立坛行道，为帝祈福。 老君命授帝太平真君之号，赐冠服符录。 师还具奏，遂改元为太平真君，大赦天下。 三年壬午岁，谦之奏曰：今陛下以真君御世，建静轮天宫之法，开古以来未之有也，应登受符书，以彰圣德。 帝从之，遂亲至法坛受符线，备法驾，旗帜皆向青，以从道家之色。 自后诸帝每即位皆受录焉。 出《后魏书》。

The Emperor, seeing that the Master partook of no earthly sustenance, accorded him even greater reverence and respect. Upon beholding the talismans and registers, his heart swelled with devotion and faith. Thereupon, he established the Terrace of the Mysterious Capital, erected the Palace of Serene Wheels in Heaven, and convened a grand assembly in accordance with ritual. The Master and his disciples all donned immortal robes and celestial crowns, their luminous presence resplendent. The Emperor wished to bestow upon the Master and his disciples high ranks and titles, but they firmly declined, accepting only the rites due to those beyond the mundane realm. By imperial decree, the Master and his disciples were ranked above princes and dukes, yet they refused, insisting on the proper forms of address. Thus, the new teachings were proclaimed and disseminated throughout the realm, greatly propagating the transformation of purity, stillness, and non-action.

Separately, one hundred and twenty disciples of virtuous conduct were selected from noble families to become Daoists. In the seventeenth year, the gengchen year, the Master established a terrace upon the lofty peaks to perform the Daoist rites and pray for blessings upon the Emperor. The Lord Lao commanded that the Emperor be granted the title "True Lord of Grand Peace," bestowing upon him a crown, robes, talismans, and registers. The Master returned and presented this in full report, whereupon the reign title was changed to "True Lord of Grand Peace," and a general amnesty was declared throughout the empire.

In the third year, the renwu year, Qianzhi memorialized: “Now that Your Majesty governs the age as the True Lord, having established the rites of the Palace of Serene Wheels in Heaven—an achievement unparalleled since antiquity—it is fitting that you ascend to receive the talismanic writ, thereby manifesting your sagely virtue.” The Emperor assented and personally approached the ritual terrace to receive the talismanic threads. His ceremonial procession was fully arrayed, with banners and standards all turned toward the color of blue-green, in accordance with Daoist tradition. Thereafter, each succeeding emperor, upon ascending the throne, received the registers in like manner.

*From the* History of the Later Wei.

chunks.original_text: 混元圣纪卷之七竟 #1『如』字原作『知』，据《辑要》本改。 #2『边』字原作『迎』，据《辑要》本改。 #3『不』字原作『以』，据《辑要》本改。 #4『十』字原作『人』，据《辑要》本改。 #5『着』字原作『者』，据《辑要》本改。 混元圣纪卷之八 宋观复大师高士谢守濒编 周武帝建德三年五月丙子，除浮屠教，悉毁经像。 又下议欲废道教，诏道士严达问曰：道与释孰优。 达曰：主优客劣。 帝曰：主客奚辩。 曰：释出西域，得非客乎，道在中夏，得非主乎。 帝曰：客既西归，主无送耶。 达曰：客归则有益於胡土，主在则无损中华，去者不追，居者自保，不亦可乎。 帝嘉其对，然业已建议，遂并断之，止留五岳观庙而已。 六月丙午，帝将视朝，忽见黄衣使者自空中持玉版丹书告〝曰：太上有敕。 帝愕然，不觉下拜。 使者以诏示帝曰：告宇文邕，大道经教，一旦古长存，所以保制天地，济度生灵，何关尔事，而辄行废黜。 以尔为世主，乃蔑弃天命，自绝於天，非天弃汝，胡为稔恶，将速厥辜。 帝览之再三，使者曰：天命靡常，不可久稽。 即收诏，腾空而去。 帝惊惧累日，乃复建通道观於都城，命严达主之，仍召诸山方士讲《道德经》。 戊午，下诏曰：至道弘深，混成无际，体包空有，理极玄幽。 但岐路既分，源流愈远，淳漓朴散，形器斯乖，遂使三墨八儒朱紫交竞，九流七略异说相腾，道隐小成，其来旧矣，不有会归，争核靡息。 今可立通道观於都城，圣哲微言，先贤典训，金科玉篆，秘迹玄文，可以济养黎元，扶成教义者，并宜弘阐，一以贯之，俾夫骯培搂者识嵩岱之崇崛，守碛砾者悟渤海之泓澄，不亦可乎。 乃命裒九流之书，摘其合於道者，并付《道藏》。 隋大业七年辛未，炀帝亲驾征辽，楼观道士岐晖谓门弟子曰：天道将改，吾犹及见之，不过数岁矣。 或问曰：不知来者若何。 曰：当有老君子孙治世，此后吾教大与，但恐微躯不能久保耳。 后数年，隋果乱。 大业十三年丁丑，老君降于终南山，语山人李淳风曰：唐公当受天命。 淳风由是归唐。 出《金锁流珠》。 唐高祖皇帝初起义兵於晋阳，帝女平阳公主，柴绍妻也，亦起兵应帝，屯於宜寿宫。 晖逆知真主将出，尽以观中资粮给其军。 及帝至蒲津关，晖喜曰：此真君来也，必乎定四方矣。 乃改名为平定以应之，仍发道士八十余人·向关应接。 帝嘉之，乃下诏曰：今束应义旗，西开幕府，设官分职，本在忠诚。 道士岐平定，铲边求真，销名离俗，恬淡荣利，无闷幽闲，而能彻损衣资以供戎服，抽割菽粟以赡军粮，忠节不嘉，理须标授，平定宜受紫金光禄大夫、已下并节级授银青光禄大夫，以酬其义。 平定力辞曰：草莽之臣应接圣君，心崇道本，黄冠不贵金紫，玄教向银青，虽奉殊私，理恐非惬。 帝曰：师且受，俟得京城，别有进止。 时隋戒牙郎将宋老生屯霍邑以拒义师，会霖雨积旬，馈运不给，高祖命旋师，太宗切谏乃止。 有白衣老父诣军门曰：余为霍山神，大上老君使谒唐公曰：八月雨止，路出霍邑束南，吾当济师。 高祖曰：此神不欺，赵元恤岂负我哉。 八月辛巳#1，高祖引师趋霍邑，斩老生，遂平霍邑。 十一月初八日，遣使诣楼观设醮祈福。
